In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. div.l: Whan that Aprill with his shoures sote
The droughte of March the ro
And bathed euery vaine in soche licoure
Of vertu engen dred is the floure
When zepherus eke with his sote breth
Inspired hath euery holte and heth
The tendre croppes and the yong sonne
Hath in the Rame halfe his course y ronne
And smale foules maken melodye
That slepen al nyght with open eye
So priketh hem nature in hir corages
Than longen folke to go on pilgrymages
And palmers for seken straunge strondes
To ferne halowes couthe in sondry londes
And specially fro euery shires ende
Of Englonde to Canterbury theye wende
The holy blisfull martir for to seke
That hem hath holpen when thay were seke
befall that in that season on a day
In Southewarke at the Taberde as I lay
Redie to g in my pilgrymage
To Cantrbury with deuoute courage
At nyght was came in to that hostelry
Well nine and twenty in a company
Of sondrie folke by auenture yfal
In feliship and pilgrimes were theay al
That towarde Canterbury woulde ryde
The chambres and the stables weren wyde
And well weren theay eased at the best
And shortly whan the sonne was to rest
So had I spoken with hem euerichone
That I was of her felishap anone
And made forwarde early for to rise
To take our way ther as I you deuise
But netheles while I haue time and space
Or thate I ferther in this tale pace
Me thinke it accordaunt to reason
To tel you al the condicion
Of eche of hem so as it seemed me
And wᵗith theay were ⁊and of what
And eke in what aray that they were
And at a knight then wil I first bigin
¶ A knight there was ⁊and þᵗat a worthy man
That fro the time þᵗat he firste began
To ryden out / he loued chiualrie
Trouthe / honour / fredom / and curteisie
Full worthy was he in his lordes warre
And therto had he ridden no man so farre
As well in cristendome at in hethinesse
And euer had honoure for his worthinesse
At Alisaundre hee was when it was won
Ful ofte time he had the bourde bigon
Abouen al nations in Pruce
In Lettowe had he ridden and in Ruce
No christen man so ofte of his degree
In Garnade at the seige had he bee
At Algezer / and riden in Belmarie
At Leyes was he / and also at Satalye
When theay were wonne / and in the great
At manye a noble armye / hadde he
At mortall battailles had he been fi
And foughten for our faith ate Tramyssene
In listes thries / and aye slaine his fo
This ilke worthy knyght had ben also
Somtime with the Lorde of Palathye
Ayenst another Hethen in Turkye
And eủer/remore / he hadde the soủer/reeyn pris
And though that he was war he was wise
And of his porte als meke as a maide
He neủer/re yite no velanye saide
In all his life to no man wight
He was a gentill parfite knyght
For to telle you of his aray
His horse weren grete but he was not gay
Of Fustean he wered a Iuppoun
All be smeryd with his haberioun
For he was late comen fro his vyage
And wente forto done his pilgremage
With hym there was a semely yonge Squier
A louere and a lusti Bachelere
Wᵗith lockes Croull as thei weren leide in presse
Of twenty yere of age he was as I gesse
Of his stature he was of euene lengthe
And bonnerly delyủer/re and grete strengthe
And he hadde ben some tyme in cheualrye
In Flaundres in artoys and in picardye
And borne hym wele as of his litle space
In hope to stonde in his ladies grace
Enbrawded he was as it were mede
All full of Fresshe floures white and rede
Singing he was or floting all day
He was as Fresshe as the monethe of May
Shorte was his gowne wᵗith sleues longe and wide
Wele couthe he sitte on hors and faire therto ride
He couthe songꝭes make and wele endite
Iuste and daunce and eke write
So hote he loued that be nighter tale
He slept no more then a nightingale
Curteise he was louly and seruisable
He carfe be fore his lorde at the table
A yeman hadde he and seruauntꝭes no moo
At that tyme wherfore hym liste to ride so
And he was clad in a cote and hode of grene
A shefe of pecoke Arowes bright and shene
Vnder his belte he bare full thriftely
Wele couthe he dresse his tackle yemanly
His arowes droped nought with feders lowe
And in his hande he bare a myghti bowe
Anotted hede hadde he wᵗith a broun vesage
Of wodecrafte couth he all the vsage
Vppon his arme he bare a gay brasere
And be his side a swerde and a bucklere
And on the tother side a gay daggere
Harneste wele sharpe as poynte of a spere
A Cristofere on his breste wele shene
An horne he bereth a baudryk of grene
A forster was he sothely as I gesse
There was a nonne also and a pⁱrioresse
That of hir swering was symple and coye
Hir grettest othe was be seynt loye
And she was called Dame Eglentyne
Full wele she songe seruise devyne
Entuned was hir voyse full semely
And Frensshe she spake full fetously
After the scole of Stratforde at the bowe
For Frensshe of Parys was to hir vnknowe
At mete full wele taught she was wᵗith all
She lete no morsell from hir lippes fall
Ne wete hir fingers in hir sause depe
Wele couthe she Carye a morsell of mete
That no drope fell vppon hir breste
In curtesye was sette mych hir liste
Hir ouer lippe wiped she full clene
That in hir coppe there was no fatte thing sene
And when she hadde dronken hir draught
Full semely after hir mete she raught
And sekerly she was of grete disporte
Off plesaunce and amyabull of poerte
And peyned hir to counterfete there
Of courte to be stately of manere
And to be holde deyne of reủer/reence
But to speken of hir conscience
She was so gentill and so piteous
She coude wepe if she sawe a mous
Kaught in a Trappe if it were dede or bledde
Full smale houndes hadde she that she fedde
Wᵗith roste flesshe mylke and wastell brede
And sorye was she if any of hem were dede
Or if men smote hem wᵗith yerde smerte
And all was conscience and tendir herte
Full semely hir wymple pinched was
Hir nose streight hir Eyen gray as glas .
Hir mouthe smale and therto softe and rede
But sekerly she hath a faire forhede
It was almoste a span brode I trowe
Full hardely she was nought vndergrowe
Full feteis was hir cloke as I was ware
Of small coralle a boute hir arme she bare
A peire of bedes gawdied all wᵗith grene
And theron hengeth a broche full shene
On which there was writen a crowned A .
And after that Amor vincit omnia
A nother nonne with hir hadde she
That was hir Chapeleyn and prestes thre
A monke there was faire for the maistry
An oute rider he loued venery
A manly man to bene an Abbote able
Full many good horse hadde he in his stable
And when he rode men myght his bridell here
Gyngeling in a whistelyng winde clere
And eke as lowde as dothe the chapell belle
There as the lorde was keper of the selle
The rule of seynt Maure or of seynt Benete
Be cause it was holde somedele streite
This Ilke monke lete olde thingꝭes passe
And helde after the newe the space
He yafe not of the text a polled henne
That seyth that hunters ben not hooly men
Ne nas a monke when that he is recheles
Is likned to a fisshe that is waterles
This to say a monke oute of Cloystre
But that text holde I not worthe anoystre
And I seide his oppyneon was good
What shulde he study and make hym self wode
Vppon a boke in cloystre all wey to poure
And swinke with handes and laboure
As augustyn haue his swinke all the worlde be serued
Let augustyn haue his swinke to hym reserued
Ther for he was a pⁱricker of right
Thre houndes he hadde as swifte as foule in flight
Was all his luste for no thing wolde he spare
Furred sleues and purfeled at the hande
Wᵗith gray and that the fynest of a lande
And softe fustyan his hode vnder the chynne
He hadde of golde wrought a coryous pynne
A loue knotte the gretter ende was
His hede was balled and shone as glas
And eke his face as he hadde bene anoynte
He was a lord fatte and in good poynte
His Eyen stepe and rolling in his hede
That semeth as a fourenesse of lede
His botes souple his hors in good state
Nowe certeynly he was a faire prelate
He was nought pale as a for pynned goste
A fatte swanne loued he beste of any roste
His Palfray was as broun as a berye
A Frere there was a wantone and a merye
A lymitoure and a full solempne man
In all the orders foure is none that wele can
So mych of Dallyance and of faire langage
He hadde made many a faire mariage
Of yonge women at his owne coste
Vnto his ordre he was anoble poste
Full wele he loued and full famulier was he
With Frankeleyns ouere all in his contre
And with worthi yemen in the town
For he hadde power of confessioıı̄un
Full swetly herde he confessioıı̄un
And plesaunt was his absolucioıı̄un
And seide hym self more then a Curate
And of his ordre he was licenciate
He was a visy man to yeve penaıı̄unce
There that he wiste to haue good pitaıı̄unce
For vnto a pore harder forto yeve
Is signe that a man is wele y shreve
For if he yaf he durste make a vaunte
He wiste that a man was repentaıı̄unte
For many a man so harde is of herte
He may not wepe all tho he sore smerte
Wherfore in stede of weping and praiers
Men moste yeve silủer/re to the pore Freres
His tippete was farsete full of knyves
And wᵗith pynnes to yeve faire wyves
And certeyn he hadde a merye note
Wele couthe he syng and play at the rote
At weddinges he bare a wey the price
His necke white was as the floure delice
Therto stronge was he as a Champioıı̄un
He knewe tauerns wele at eủer/rey town
And eủer/rey hostelere and tapestere
Better than a lazer or a beggere
To haue swich a lazer in aqueintaıı̄unce
It is nought honeste it may nought a vaunce
For to dele with swiche poraile
But all with riche and sellers of vetayle
And oủer/re all there as profite shulde arise
Curteise he was and louly of seruise
There nas no man no where so vertuous
He was the beste begger in all the house
For thegh a wedowe hadde nought a shoo
So plesaunt he was wᵗith in pⁱrincipio
Yete wolde he haue offering or he went
His purchace was wele better then his rent
And rage he couthe as a whelpe
In loue dayes couthe he mych helpe
For there he nas nought like a cloystrere
With a threde bare cope as is a pore cloystrere
But he was like a maister or a pope
Of double worstete was his semely cope
That rounde was as a belle oute of presse
Somwhat he lisped for his wantounesse
To make his Englysshe swete vppon his tonge
And his harping when he hadde songe
His Eyen twincled in his hede aright
As Dothe the sterres in the frosty night
This worthy lymetoure was called hoberde
A marchaunt there was wᵗith a forked berde
Vppon his hede a Flaundrisshe beủer/re hatte
In motley on hight on hors he sate
His botes clasped faire and fetiously
His resons he spake full solemply
Shewing all weyes the encrese of his wynnyng
He wolde the see were kept for any thyng
Be twix . myddelburghe and orwelle
Wele couth he in his eschaunge byt selle
This worthi man full wele his witte he be sette
There wiste no wight that he was in dette
So estately was he of gounaıı̄unce
With his bargayns and his cheuyssaıı̄unce
For sothe he was a worthy man wᵗith all
Bot sothe for to seyne I not howe men hym calle
A Clerke there was of Oxinforde also
That vnto logyk hadde longe y go
And lene was his horse as it were a rake
And he was right fatte I vndertake
But loked hoole and therto soberly
Full threde bare was his oủer/re courtby
For he hadde getyn hym yete no benefice
Ne he was not worthy to haue noone office
For hym was leủer/re to haue at his beddes hede
Twenty bokes clothed in blak and rede
Of Alestotile and of Philosophie
Than robes riche or fydell or sautrie
But all that he myght of his Frendes hente
On bokes and on lirnyngꝭes he spente
And besely he gan for the soules pray
For hem that yaf hym wherwᵗith to scolay
Of stody toke he moste cure and hede
Nought cone worde spake he more then was nede
Shorte and quick and of highe sentence
Some thing in morall vertue was his prudence
And gladliche wolde he lirne and gladliche teche
And therwᵗith full softe was he in his speche
A sergaunte of lawe warr and wise
That often hadde bene at parvise
That was also riche of excellence
Discrete he was and of grete reủer/reence
Hym semeth that his wordes weren full wise
Iustice he was full often in a syse
By patent and by pleyn cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science and his highe renoun
Of Fees and robes hadde he many oon
So grete a purchasoure was there neủer/re none
All was fee symple to hym in affecte
His purchasing myght not be to hym in suspecte
No where was so besy a man as he there nas
And yite he semed besier then he was
In termes hadde he case and domes all
That fro the tyme of king William were falle
Therto he couthe Endite and make a thing
There couthe no wight pinche at his writing
And eủer/rey statute couthe he pleyne by rote
He rode but homely in a myddell cote
Y gyrte wᵗith a seynt of silke and barres smale
Of his aray telle I no leng tale
A Frankeleyn was there in his companye
White was his berde as was the dayes Eye
And of his complexcioıı̄un he was sangueyn
To lif in delite was eủer/re his wone
For he was Epicuris owne sone
That helde oppenyon that pleyn delite
Was veray felicite parfite
An house holder was and that a grete he
Seynt Iulian he was in his contre
His brede his ale was all wey after oone
A better vetayled man was there neủer/re noone
With oute bake mete was he neủer/re in his house
His Fisshe his flesshe and that so plenteouse
It shewed in his house of mete and drinke
Of all deyntes that men couth thinke
After the sondry sesone of the yere
So chaunged he his mete and his soupere
Full many a fatte partriche hadde he in mewe
And many a breme and luce in stewe
Wo was his coke but his sauce were
Poynaıı̄unt and sharpe and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle all weye
Stode redy coủer/reed all the longe day
At Cessions there was lorde and syre
Full often tyme he was knyght of the shyre
A lase and a gypser of silke
Henge at his gyrdill white as morowe mylke
A sheref hadde he bene and a countour
Was neủer/re no where swich a worthi lauasour
A haberdassher . and a Carpentere
A Webbe a Dyer . and a tapestere
And thei were clothed all in oone leveray
Of a solempne and a grete fraternyte
Full Fresshe and newe they piked was
Her knyves were not chaped wᵗith Bras
But all wᵗith silủer/re wrought full clene and wele
Her girdels and her pouches eủer/reydele
Wele semeth Ilke of hem a fatte burgeys
To sitte atte yelde halle at the deys
Eủer/reych for the wisdame that he can
Was happy forto bene thi aldre man
For catell hadde thei ynough and rente
And her wyves wolde therto assent
And elles certeyn thei were to blame
It is full faire to be called medame
And go to the vegyll all be fore
And haue a mantyll royally y bore
A Coke they hadde with hem for the nones
To boyle chekyns with the mary bones
And pouder marchaunt tarte and galyngale
Wele couthe he knowe a Draught of good ale
He couthe roste sethe boyle and Frye
Make mortreux and wele bake a pye
But grete harme was it as it semed me
That on his chyn a mormall hadde he
For blank manger made he with the beste
A shipman was there that wonneth ferr by weste
For ought I wote he was of Dertmouthe
He rode vppon a rounsy as he couthe
In a gowne of Faldyng to the kne
A dagger hanging on a lase hadde he
A boute his necke vnder his arme a doun
The hote somer hadde made his hewe all broun
And serteynly he was a good felawe
Full many a draught of wyne hadde he drawe
Fro burdeux warde whiles that the shipmen slepte
Of conscience rought he ne kepte
And at full many a batayle in that londe
Hadde he foughten and hadde the bett̉er/re honde
But of his crafte to reken wele his tides
His stremes and his daungers hym besides
There nas noone swich fro hulle vnto Cartage
For wise he was thogh he were full of corage
Hardy he was and ware to vndertaken
With many a tempeste his berde hath bene shaken
He knewe all the hauens as thei boıı̄unde were
Fro Englonde to the Capfenestre
And eủer/rey Creke in bretayne and in spayne
With vs there was a doctoᵘur of Fesyke
In all the worlde was there none hym like
To speke of Fesyke and of surgery
For he was grounded in astronomy
He kept his pacience a full grete dele
In vs he markete naturell
Wele couthe he of fortune the accident
Of his ymage for he was pacient
He knewe the cause of eủer/rey maledy
Were it of hete colde moyste or dry
Howe it was engendred and of what humore
He was a verey parfite practisoure
The cause he knewe of his harme by rote
Anoone he yafe the seke man his bote
For redy he was at the potecaries
To sende hym drugges and his letwaries
For Ilke of hem made other forto wynne
Her frendship was nought newe to begynne
For wele knewe he the olde osculapius
And discorde eke and Ruphus
Olde ypocras halye and eke galyane
Serapion Crasy and eke Nysene
Auorros Damastion and Costantyn
Bernard gatesdane and gilbertyn
Of his dyete mesurable was he
For it was noone of suꝑper/parfluyte
But of grete norysshing and degestyble
His studie was nought but litle on the bible
In sangueyn and in a party cladde wᵗith all
Elyned with Taffata and with sendall
And yite he was but Esy of dispence
He kept that he wan in tyme of pestilence
For golde in Fesyke is a cordyall
Therfore he loued golde in speciall
A good wiffe there was of be side Bathe
She was somdele defe and that was skathe
Of clothe making hadde she swich an haunte
She passed hem of Ipres and of Gaunte
In all the paresshe wife was there none
That to the offeryng be fore hir shulde gone
And if they Did certeyn wrothe was she
That she was oute of all charite
Hir kerchefes full fyne were of grounde
I durste swere they weyed doun a pounde
That eủer/rey sonday were on hir hede
Hir hosen were of fyne scarlete rede
Full streite . y teyed and shone full newe
Bolde was hir face faire and rede of hewe
She was a worthy woman all hir lyve
Housbandes at the chirche dorre she hadde fyve
With oute other companye in her youthe
But it nedeth not to speke as in youthe
And ypres hadde she be and at Ierusalem
She hadde passed many a stronge streme
At Rome hadde she bene and at babiloyne
In galece at seynt Iames and at Coleyne
She couthe myche of wandryng in the weye
Gaptothe she was the sothe forto seye
Vppon an awmblere full Esely she sate
Y wympled wele and on hir hede an hatte
As brode as it were a boklere or a targe
A good mantyll a boute hir hippes large
And on hir heelys a paire of sporres sharpe
In felawship couthe wele carpe
Of remedies of louers couthe she ꝑper/parchaunce
For of that arte she couthe wele daunce
A good man there was of religeoun
And he was a pore persone of a town
But riche he was and hooly of werke
That truly cristes gospell wolde preche
His paresshons devoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was and wonder deligent
And in adủer/resite he was full pacient
And suche as he was proffred often sithes
Full lothe hym were to courte for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeve oute of doute
Vnto his pore paresshons a boute
Of his offeryng and of his sustenaıı̄unce
He couthe in litle thing haue suffisaunce
Wyde was his paresshe and houses ferr a sonder
But he lete nought for reyne ne thonder
In sekenesse and in mysschief to vesyte
The ferrest in his paresshe more and lesse
Vppon his fete and in his hande a staff
This noble Ensaumple to his shepe he yaf
That firste wrought and after he taught
Oute of the Gospell the wordes he caught
And this Figure he yafe ther to
That if golde ruste what shulde Irne do
For if a preste be foule in whome we trust
No wonder is a lewde man to mystrust
And shame it is if a preste take kepe
A shiten shepharde and a clene shepe
Wele ought a preste ensaumple forto yeve
By his clennesse howe his shepe shulde lyve
Ne sette not his benefice to hyre
And lette his shepe acombred in the myre
And renne to london to seynt poules
To seken hym a chauntry for soules
Or with a bretherhed to bene holde
But Dwellyng at home and kepe his folde
So that the wolf ne hadde nought meskarye
He was a sheparde and nought a mercenarye
And though he hooly were and vertuouse
He was not to symple men dispiteouse
But in his speche discrete and benigne
Ne in no wise daıı̄ungerous ne digne
To drawe folke to honoᵘur with fairenesse
By good ensaumple this was his besynesse
But it were any persone abstynate
Who so were of lowe degre or hye of astate
Hym wolde he snebbe shortly for the nones
A bett̉er/re preest I trowe goth nought on bones
He waited after no pompe nor reủer/reence
Ne made hym none spised conscience
But Cristes lore and his apostels twelve
He taught but firste he folowed hem hym selve
With hym there was a plough man that was his brother
That hadde y ledde of donge many a Fother
A true swinker and a good herde was he
Levyng in pees and in parfite charite
God loved he best with all his herte
And at all tyme though he be gan to smerte
And than his neghburgh right as hym selue
He wolde trust and therto Dyke and Delue
For cristes sake for eủer/rey pore wight
With outen hyre if it lay in his myght
His tithes paide he bothe faire and wele
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and his catele
In a tabarde he rode vppon a mere
There was also a Reve and eke a mylnere
A somnere and a pardon also
A maunsyple and my self there was no moo
This Milnere was a stoute karle for the nones
Full bigge he was of brawne and bones
That proved welle for eủer/re where that he came
At wrestling all wey he wolde haue the game
He was shorte shuldred and a thuk gnarre
Ther nas no dorre that nolde lifte of a barre
Or breke it at rennyng with his hede
His berde as any wexe was rede
And therto brode as it were a spade
Vppon the coppe of his nose he hadde
A werte and there on stode a tofte of heeres
Rede as the brystill of a swyne heeres
His nose thrilles black were and wyde
A swerde a bokelere bare he be his syde
His mouthe as grete as a foureneys
He was a Ianglere and a Ioly arteys
And that was moste of synne he vsed harletrye
Wele couthe he stele corne and tolle thrye
And that he hadde a thoumbe of golde parde
A white cote and a blak hode wered he
A bagge pipe couthe he blowe and sown
And ther with he brought vs all oute of town
A gentyll maunciple was there of a temple
Of which a catoᵘur myght take ensaumple
For to bene wise in bigging of vetayle
For whether he peide or toke be a tayle
Algate he waited so on his akate
That he was ay before and in good state
Nowe it not that of god a faire grace
That swich a lewde man his wit shall passe
The wisdome of an hepe of lirned men
Of maisters he hadde moo then thries ten
That were experte of lawes and Curyous
Of which there was a doseyn in that house
Worthi to ben stewardes of house and londe
Of any lorde that is in Englonde
To make hym lyve bi his owne good
In honoᵘur doutles but if he were wode
Or lyve as chepely as hym liste to desyre
And forto helpen all the shyre
In any case that myght falle or happe
And yite this maunsiple sette vp all her cappe
The reve was a sklender coloured man
His berde was shave as nygh as he can
His heere was bi his Eres rounde y shore
His Toppe was doket like a preest be fore
Full longe was his legges and full lene
Lyke a staf there nas no calf sene
Wele couthe he kepe a garnere and a bynne
There was none auditoᵘur couthe of hym wynne
Wele wiste he bi the drought and be the reyne
The yelding of his sede and of his greyne
His lordes shepe his nette and his daire
His swyne his horse store and his pultrie
Was holy in this Reves goủer/renaunce
And bi his Couenᵃnte yafe he attendaıı̄unce
Sithens his lorde was twenty yere of age
There couthe no man bring hym in rerage
There nas bayle ne herde ne no nother hyne
That he ne couthe his sleight and his covyne
Thei were of hym a drad as of the dethe
His wonnyng was faire vppon a hethe
With grene trees shadowed was his place
He couthe better then his lorde purchace
Full riche he was and stored pⁱrively
His lorde he couthe plese discretly
To ben ayeins hym of his owne good
And haue a thanke and yete a cote and a hode
In youthe he hadde lirned a good mystere
He was a wele good wright and a carpentere
This Reve . sate vppon a wele good stotte
That was all pomell grey and highe shotte
A longe surcote of pers vppon he hadde
And be his side he bare a rusty blade
Of norffolk was this reve which I telle
Besides a towne men calle it Baldeswelle
Tuked he was as is a Frere a boute
And eủer/re he rode the hindrest of oure route
A Somonoure was there wᵗith vs in that place
That hadde a faire rede cherubyn face
For sauuceflemyd he was with Eyen narowe
But he was as a likerous as a sparowe
With blak browes scalled and pilled berde
Of his vesage children weren full sore a ferde
There nas quick silủer/re licoure ne brymstone
Borage ceruse ne oyle of tartre none
Ne Oynement that iched and bite
That myght helpe hym of his welkes white
Ne of his knobbys sittyng on his chekes
Wele he loued garleke onyoıı̄uns and lekes
And forto drynke rede wyne as rede as the blode
Than wolde he speke and crie as he were wode
And when he hadde wele dronken the wyne
Then wolde he speke no word but latyne
A fewe termes hadde he ij . or thre
That he hadde lirned oute of some degre
No wonder is he herde it all the Day
And eke he knewe wele that aray
He can clepe watte as wele as the pope
But he couthe hym in other thinges grope
Then he spende all his philosophie
A question quod queris wolde he crie
He was a gentill harlote and a kinde
A better felawe shulde no man finde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felawe to haue his concubyne
A twelmoneth and excuse hym at the fulle
Full pⁱrively a fynche couthe he pulle
And if he founde owhere a good felawe
He wolde teche hym anoone to haue awe
In swich case of the Erchdekens curse
But if mannes soule were in his purse
For in his purs he shulde pinched be
Purs is the Erchdekens hele seide he
But wele I wote he lied in dede
Of curse ought eủer/rey man to drede
But cursing wil slee right as a soyling saveth
And also war hym of significauit
In daung hadde he at his owne gise
The yonge girles of all the dieses
And knewe of her counseyle and of her rede
A garlande he hadde sette vppon his hede
As grete as it were an ale stake
A bokelere hadde he made of a cake
With hym there rode a gentyll pardon
Of rouncyvale his Frende and his compere
That streight was come from the pope of rome
Full lowde he songe come hidder loue come
This Pardon bare to hym a chief burdoıı̄un
Was neủer/re trompe of half so grete soun
This pardon hadde heere as yelowe as wexe
But it henge as it were a stryke of flexe
By vnces henge his lokkes that he hadde
And therwith were his shuldres spradde
But then it lay bi culpons oone and oone
And hode for Iolite ware he noone
For it was trussed vp in his walet
Hym thought he rode all on the newe gette
Vnshebelled sauf his cappe all bare
Suche glarynge yen had he as hath an hare
His walete be fore hym he bare in his lappe
A vernecle hadde he sowed vppon his cappe
Frette full of pardone come from rome all hote
A voyse he hadde as smalle as a gote
No berde hadde he ne none shulde he haue
As myche were it as it were newe shaue
I trowe he were a gelding or . a mare
But of his crafte from warrwik vnto ware
Ne was there neủer/re suche a pardonere
For in his male he hadde a pelowe bere
Which he seide was oure ladies vayle
He hadde he seide a gobette of the sayle
That seynte Petir hadde when he wente
Vppon the see till Ihc crist hym hente
He hadde a crosse of latone full of stones
And glas he hadde full of pigges bones
But with thes reliques that he founde
A poủer/ree persone dwelling vp londe
Vppon a day he gate hym more money
Than that persone gate in monethes twey
Thus hath he serued wᵗith flateryng Iapes
He made the persone and the peple his apes
But truly to telle at the laste
He was in chirche a noble celestiate
Wele couthe he rede a lessone or a storye
But alther beste sange he in a fraterye
For wele he wiste when that songe was songe
He moste preche and wele rule his tonge
To wynne silủer/re as he wele couthe
Therfore he songe the meryer and louthe
NOwe haue I tolde you in a clause
The state the array and eke the cause
Why that insemble was this cōmpanye
In southwerke at the gentill hostlerye
That hight the tabarde faste by the belle
But nowe is tyme you forto telle
How that we bare vs that ilke night
When that we weren in that hostelery a light
And after wil I telle of oure vyage
And all the Couenaunt of oure pilgremage
But first I pray you of youre curtesye
That ye ne take it nought for no velenye
Though that I speke pleynly in this matere
To telle you here wordes here and there
Ne though I speke her . wordes ꝓproprely
For this ye knowe as wele as I .
Who shall telle a tale after a mayn
He moste reherce as nye as he can
Eủer/rey worde if it be in his charge
All though he speke sothly and to large
Or elles he moste telle his tale vntrue
Or fayne thinges or finde wordes newe
He may not spare all though he were his brother
He moste as wele sey oone worde as a nothere
Crist spake hym selue full brode in hooly writte
And wele I wote no veleny is it
Eke plato seide who so can it rede
The wordes most ben chosen to the dede
Also I pray you for yeue it me
All if I haue nought sette folkꝭes in her degre
Here in this tales as they sholde stonde
My wit is shorte ye may wele vnderstonde
Grete chere made oure hoste to vs eủer/reychone
And to the souper sette he vs anoone
He serued vs with vetayle at the beste
Stronge was the wyne and wele drynke vs liste
A semely man oure hoste was with all
Forto bene a marshall in a lordes halle
A large man he was with Eyen stepe
A faire burgeys there nys none suche in chepe
Bolde of his speche he was and wele taught
And of manhede lacketh he right nought
Eke therto he was right a mery man
And after souper to pley he began
And spake of myrthe amonge other thinges
When he hadde made oure rekenynges
And seide thus nowe lordinges truly
Ye bene to me right welcome hertely
For by my trouthe if I shall not lie
I sawe not this yere so mery a companye
At oones in this hostery as is nowe
Fayne wolde I do you myrthe and I wiste howe
And of my myrthe I am right nowe be thought
To do you cause and it shall coste you nought
Ye wil to cauntirbury god you spede
The blisfull martir quyte you youre mede
And wil ye wete as ye go bi the way
Ye shapen you to talken and to play
For truly comforte ne myrthe it is noone
To ride bi the way as doume as a stone
And therfore wil I make you disporte
As I seide erste and done you comforte
And if it like you all by oone assent
Forto stonde to my Iuggement
And to werke as I shall you sey
To morowe when ye ride bi the wey
Nowe be my Faders soule that is dede
But if ye be merye I shall lese myn hede
Holde vp youre handes with outen more speche
Oure counseyle shall nought be longe forto seche
We thought it was nought worth to make vs wise
And graunted hym with oute more devise
And bade hym sey his wordes as hym liste
Lordinges quod he herkenyth for the beste
But take it nought I pray you in disdeyn
This is the poynte to speke it shorte and pleyn
That Ilke of you to shorte with youre wey
In this viage shall telle talys twey
To Cauntirbury warde I mene it so
And homwarde he shall telle other tales twoo
Of aventurs that whilome hath bifalle
And which of you that bereth hym beste of all
That is to sey that telleth in his case
Tales of beste sentence and moste of solace
Shall haue a souper of youre alther coste
Here in this place sitting bi this poste
When that we come ageyn from Cauntirbury
And forto make you the more merye
I wil my self goodly with you ryde
Right at myn owne coste and bene yoᵘur gyde
And who that wil my Iuggement with sey
Shall pey all that is spended bi the way
And if ye wil that it be so
Telle me anoone with oute wordes moo
And I wil hardely shape me therfore
This thing was graunted and othes swore
With full gladde herte and praying hem also
That he wil vouchesauf so forto doo
And that he wil bene oure gouernoure
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoure
And sette a souper at a serteyn pris
And we wil be ruled at his Devise
Highe and lowe and all by oone assent
We bene acorded to the Iuggement
And ther vppon the wyne was fette anoone
Wyne dronken and to oure reste wente Ilke oone
With outen any leng tarying
A morowe when the day gan to spryng
Vp rose oure hoste and was all oure koke
And gadred vs all on a faire flok
And forthe we riden a litle morowe pace
Vnto the wateryng of seynt Thomas
And there oure hoste bigan his hors areste
And seide herkenyth lordinges if ye liste
Ye wote oure forwarde and I you recorde
Yf Eueson or morwe songe acorde
Lette se nowe who shall telle the firste tale
As eủer/re mote he drynke wyne or ale
Who so wil be rebell to my Iuggement
Shall pay for all that ye bi the way spent
Nowe draweth lotte er that ye firther twynne
The which shall the firste tale be gynne
Sir knyght quod he my maister and my lorde
Draweth Cutte for that is myn acorde
Come nere qd . he my lady prioresse
And ye Sir clerke lette be youre stedfastnesse
Now stonde not still ley on hande eủer/rey man
Anoone to drawe eủer/rey wight began
And shortly to telle as it was
Were it bi auenture shorte or caas
The sothe is thus the cutte fell on the knyght
Of which full blithe and gladde was eủer/rey wight
And telle he moste his tale as it was resone
By forwarde and by composicioıı̄un
As ye haue herde what nedeth wordes moo
And when this good man sawe that it was so
As he that wise was and obedient
To kepe his forward bi his Fre assent
He seide sithen I shall be gynne the game
What welcome be the Cutte a goddis name
Nowe lete vs ryde and herkenyth what I sey
And with that worde we riden forthe on oure wey
And he be gan with right a merye chere
His seide anoone this tale as ye shall here
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
(base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
(base) Forth he rode with grete power and myght
(base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte
(base) ¶ But shortly / for to speken of this thyng
(base) With Creoun / which that was of Thebes kyng
(base) He faught and slow hym manly / as a knyght
(base) In pleyn bataille / and putte the folk to flyght
(base) And by assaut he wan the Citee after
(base) And rente adoun / bothe wal / and sparre / and rafter
(base) And to the ladyes / he restored agayn
(base) The bones / of hir freendes / that were slayn
(base) To doon obsequies / as was tho the gyse
(base) But it weere al to long for to deuyse
(base) The grete clamour / and the waymentynge
(base) That the ladyes made / at the brennynge
(base) Of the bodies / and the grete honour
(base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon

div.l: (base) Ther as by auenture / this Palamoun

(base) The blood roial / of Cadme and Amphioun
(base) ¶ Of Cadmus / which that was the firste man

div.l: (base) ¶ Allas thow felle Mars / allas Iuno

div.l: (base) Thow sholdest neuere / out of this groue pace

div.l: (base) For outher / I moot sleen hym / at the gappe

div.l: (base) Vpon a lord / that wol haue no mercy

(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue

div.l: (base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
(base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee

¶ Prologus Milnere
Whenne the knyght hadde thus his tale tolde

And wele worthy to be drawe in memorye
And namely the gentyls Eủer/reychone ¶ꝐPer/Par

Somewhat to quyte with the knyghtꝭes tale

It is a synne and eke a grete folye
To a paire any man or hym do fame
And eke to bryng wives in Evile name
Thou maiste Enough of other thinges seyne
This dronken mylnere spake full soone ageyn

Of goddis pⁱrivety ne of his wif
So that he fynde goddes foysone there
Of the remenaunt nede nought to enquere
What sholde I sey but that this proude Miln

Me a thinketh that I shall reherce here
And therfore eủer/rey gentill which I pray
For goddis loue as deme nought that I sey

Her wordes all be they bett̉er/re or worse

And therfore who so lysteth nought to here
Turne oủer/re the lefe and chese another tale
For he shall fynde Enough bothe grete and smale
Of storyall thinges that toucheth gentilnesse
And eke more royall and of holynesse
Blameth nought if that ye chese amysse
The myln is a cherle ye knowe wele this
So was the reve and other many moo

Avise you I put me oute of blame
And men shall make ernest of game
Whilome there was dwellyng in Oxinforde

With hym there was dwellyng a pore scollere
Hadde lyrned arte but all his fantesy

And couthe a certeyn of conclusyoıı̄uns
For to deme by interrogacioıı̄uns
If that men asked hym in serteyn ours

For he hadde more towe on his distaf

That hote Cultere in thy chymney here
As lenethe me I haue therwith to done
I wil it to the bryng ayein full soone
Gerveys answerde Certeis were it golde
Or in a poke nobles all vntolde
Ye shuld haue as I am true smyth
Eye cristes peyn what wil ye do ther wᵗith
Ther of qd absalon be as it be may
I shall it wele the telle it to morowe day
And kaught the culter bi the olde stele
Full softe oute at the dore he gan stele
And wente vnto the carpenters walle
He koughed firste and knokked therwᵗithall
Vppon the wyndowe right as he did ere
This Alysone answerde who is there
That knoketh so I warante it a thefe
Why nay qd he god wote my swete leef
I am thyn absalon O my derlyng
Of golde qd he I haue brought the a ryng
My moder yaf it me so god me saue
Full fyne it is and therto wele y graue
This wil I yeve the if thou me kysse
This nycholas was risen forto pisse
And thought to amende all the Iape
He shulde kisse his Ers er that he thens scape
And vp the wyndowe did he hastely
And oute his ers put he pⁱriuely
Ou the buttokes to the haunche bone
And therwᵗith spake this clerke this absalon
Speke swete bryd I not where thou arte
This nycholas anoone lete flye a farte
As grete as it hadde be a thunder dynte
And with that stroke he was almoste blynte
And was redy with his Iren hote
And nycholas amydde the ers he smote
Of gothe the skyn an hande brede all a boute
The hote cultere brende so his toute
That for the smerte he wende forto deye
As he were wode anoone he gan to crye
Helpe water water helpe for goddis herte
This carpenter oute of his slom sterte
And herde oone crye water as he were wode
And thought allas for nowe cometh noes flode
He sette hym vp with outen wordes moo
And with his axe he smote the corde awoo
And doun he gothe he founde nother to selle
Brede ne ale till he come to the selle
Vppon the flore and there a swone he lay
And vp sterte alisone and nycholay
And cried oute and harowe in the strete
The neighbores bothe smale and grete
In rennen forto garen on this man
That a swoune lay bothe pale and wan
For with the falle broken he hadde his arme
But stonde he moste nedes to his owne harme
For when he spake he was anoone borne doun
With hende nycholas and faire alisone
They talken euy man that he was wode
He was agaste and ferde of noes flode
Thrugh fantesye that of vanyte
He hadde kaught in knedyng tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged in the rofe aboue
And that he prayeth hem for goddis loue
To sitten in the rofe par companye
The folkes gan to laugh at his fantesye
In to the rofe they keken and gape
And turne all his harme into a Iape
For what so the carpenter answerde
It was for nought no man his resone herde
With othes grete he was sworne a doun
That he was holden wode in all the town
For euy clerke helde with other
They seide the man was wode my lefe brother
And euy man gan to laughe at this stryf
Thus was swyfed the carpenters wyf
For all his kepyng and his Ielousye
And absalon hath kyste hir nether Eye
And nycholas is scalded in the toute
This tale is done god saue all the route

Here Endeth the mylners tale and
begynneth the prolage of the Reve
