So full of synne is many a creature
O myghti god if that it be thy wille
Sith thou arte rightfull Iugge howe may it be
That thou wilte suffer Innocentes to spill
And wicked folkes to reigne in ꝓprosperite
O good Custance Allas so woo is me
That I moste be thy tormentoᵘur or elles deye
On shames dethe there is no nother weye
Weping wᵗith yonge and olde in that place
When that the king this cursed lre sente
And Custance with a dedly pale face
The fourte day toward hir ship wente
But natheles she toke it in good entente
The wil of crist and knelyng in the stronde
She seide eủer/re welcome be thy sonde
He that me kept fro the fals blame
While I was on the londe amonge you
He can kepe me fro harme and eke fro shame
In salte see all thogh I sey not howe
As stronge as eủer/re he was he is right nowe
In hym trust I and in his moder dere
That is to my seile and eke maistere
Hir litell childe lay wepyng in hir arme
And knelyng pitously to hem she seide
Pees litell childe I wil do the no harme
With that hir kerchief of hir hede she breide
And oủer/re hir litell sone Eyen she it leide
And in hir arme she lulleth it full faste
And into heuene vp hir Eyen she caste
Moder qd she and maide bright marie ¶
Sothe is that throgh womans Egmente
Mankinde was lorne and dampned ay to deye
For which thy childe was on Cros y rente
Thy blisfull Eyen sawe all his turnemente
Then is there none comparisone bitwene
Thy woo and any woman may Susteyne
Thou sawe thy sone sleyne be fore thyn Eyen
And yite nowe lyveth my litell childe ꝑper/parfay
Thou glorye of womanhede thou faire may
Thou hauen of refuyte bright sterre of day
Rewe on my childe that of thy gentilnesse
Rewest on eủer/rey rightfull in distresse
O litell childe allas what is thy gilte
That neủer/re wrought synne as yete parde
Why wil thy harde Fadir haue the spilte
O mercy dere constable qd she
As lete my litell childe dwelle here wᵗith the
And if thou darste nought kepe hym for blame
So kys hym oones in his Faders name
Therwith she loketh bakwarde to the londe
And seide farewele housbonde douteles
And vp she ryste and walketh doun the stronde
Towarde the ship hir foloweth all the prees
And eủer/re she precheth hir childe to holde his pees
And taketh hir leue with an holy entente
She blesseth hir and into ship she wente
Vetaylled was the shipp it is no drede
Habundauntly for hir full longe space
And other necessaries that shulde nede
She hadde enoghe heryed be goddis grace
For wynde and wedir all myghti god purchace
And bryng hir home I can no bett̉er/re seye
But in the see she dryueth forth hir weye
Alba the kyng cometh home soone aftir this
Vnto his castell which I of tolde
And asked where his wyf and his childe is
The constable be gan a boute his herte colde
And pleynly all the man he hym tolde
As ye haue herde I can telle it no better
And shewith the kyng his sele and his letter
And seide lorde as ye cōmmaund me
Vppeyn of dethe so haue I done certeyn
This messengere turmented was till he ¶
Moste be knowen and telle plat and pleyn
Fro nyght to nyght in what place he hadde leyn
And thus be witte and subtilly enqueryng
Ymagined by whome this harme gan spryng
The hande was knowen that the lre wrote
And all the venyme of this Cursed dede
But in what wise Certeynly I ne wote
The effecte is this that alba oute of drede
His moder slowe that may men pleynly rede
For that she traytoᵘur was to hir ligence
This endeth olde Donegilde wᵗith mysschaıı̄unce
The sorowe that this alba nyght and day
Maketh for his wyf and his childe also
There is no thing that it telle may
But nowe wil I vnto Custance go
That fleteth in the see in peyne and in woo
Fyve yere and more as liketh Cristes sonde
Or that hir shipp approched into londe
Vnder an hethen castell at the laste
Of which the name in my text nought I fynde
Custance and eke hir childe the see vp caste
All myghti god that saueth all mankynde
Haue of Custance and hir childe some mynde
That fallen is in hethen honde efte soone
In poynte to spill as I shall telle you soone
Doun fro the castell cometh there many a wight
To gawren on the ship and on Custance
But shortly fro the castell on a nyght
The lordes steward god yeve hym mysschaıı̄unce
A thefe that Renyed oure creance
Come into ship and seide aloone he shulde
Hir lēmman be wher she wolde or nolde
Woo was this wrecched woman wo be gone
Hir childe cryed and she cryed pitously
But blesfull marie halpe hir right anoone
For with hir struggelyng wele and myghtely
The thef felle oủer/reborde all sodenly
And in the see he dreynt for vengeaıı̄unce
And thus hath crist vnwemmed kept Custance
O foule luste of luxurie lo thyn ende
Noght only that thou faynteste mannes mynde
But verrely thou wilte his body shende
The ende of thy werke or of thy lustes blynde ¶
Is compleynyng howe many oone may men fynde
That noght for werkꝭes Some tyme but for the entent
To done this Synne be other slayne or shente
Howe myght this wayke woman haue the strengthe
Hir to defende ageyn this Renegate
O golyas vn mesurable of lengthe
How myght dauid make the so mate
So yonge and of armoᵘur so desolate
How durste he loke vppon thy dredfull face
Wele may men se it was but goddis grace
Who yaf Iudyssh corage or hardynesse
For to sle Olyfernus in his tente
And to delyủer/re oute of wrechednesse
The peple of god I sey for this entent
That right as god spereth and vigoure sente
To hym and saued hem oute of mysschaıı̄unce
So send he myght and vygore to Custance
For sothe hir ship past throwe the narowe mouthe
Of uybalcar and Cepte dryuyng evere
Some tyme weste and some tyme northe and South
And some tyme Est full many a wery day
Till Cristes moder blessid mote she be ay
Hath shapen throgh hir endlesse goodnesse
To make an ende of all hir heuynesse
Nowe lete vs stynte of Custance but a throwe
And speke of the Romayne Emꝑper/paroᵘur
That oute of Surrey hath he lete hir knowe
The slaughter of cristen folkꝭes and dishonoure
Done to his doughter by a fals traytoure
I meene the Cursed wicked Sawdannesse
That at the feste lete sle bothe more and lesse
For which the Emꝑper/paroᵘur hath sente anoone
His senatoure with royall ordenaunce
And other lordes god wote many oone
On surreyns to taken his vengeaıı̄unce
They brenne slee and brynge hem to mysschaıı̄unce
Full many a day but shortly this is the ende
Homwarde to Rome they shapen hem to wende
This Senatoure retourneth with victorye
To romewarde Seyllyng full royally
And mete the shippe dryvyng as seyth the storye
In which Custance sate full pitously
No thing ne knewe he what she was ne why She was¶
She was in such array ne she nyll sey
Of hir astate thogh she shulde dey
He bryngeth hir to rome and to his wyf
He yaf hir and hir yonge sone also
And with the Senatour she ladde hir lif
Thus gan oure lady bryng oute of woo
Wofull Custance and many a nother moo
And longe tyme dwelled she in that place
In hooly werkes eủer/re as it was hir grace
The Senatoures wyf hir aunte was
But for all that she knewe hir neủer/re the more
I wil no lenger tarye in this case
But to kyng Alba of which I spake of afore
That for his wyf wept and Siked sore
I wil retourne and leve I wil Custance
Vnder the senatoures goủer/renaıı̄unce
Kyng Alba which that hath his moder slayne
Vppon a day felle in suche a repentaunce
That if I shortly telle shall and pleyn
To rome cometh forto resseyue his penaıı̄unce
And put hym in the popes ordenaunce
In highe and lowe and Ihu crist be sought
For gyve his wiked werkes that he hadde wrought
The fame anoone thrugh Rome towne is borne
How alba kyng is come on pilgremage
By his herbegours that wente be forne
For which the Senatore as was the vsage
Rode ageyn hym and many of his lynage
As wele forto shewe his magnificence
As forto done any kyng reủer/reence
Grete chere dothe this Senatoure
To king Alba and he to hym also
Eủer/reyche of hem dothe other grete honoure
And so be felle that in a day or twoo
This Senatoure is to kyng alba go
To feste shortly if I shall not lye
Custance sone in his companye
Some Men wolde sey at the requeste of Custance
This Senatoure hath ladde this childe to feste
I may not telle all the circıı̄unstaıı̄unce
Be as be may there was he at the leste
But sothe is this that at his moder heste
Be fore alba duryng the mete while and space ¶
The childe stode lokyng on the kyngꝭes face
This alba kyng hath of the childe grete wonder
And to the Senatoure he seide anoone
Whos is that faire childe that stante yonder
I not qd he be god and be seynt Iohn
A moder he hath but Fadir hath he none
That I of wote and shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alba that this childe was founde
But god wote qd this Senatoᵘur also
So vertuouse a lyver in my lif
Ne sawe I neủer/re as I ne herde of moo
Of wordly women mayde ne of wyf
I dare wele sey she hadde leủer/re a knyf
Throgh hir breste wente than to be a woman wykke
There is no man couthe brynge hir to that prykke
Nowe was this childe as like vnto Custaıı̄unce
As possible as is a creature to be
This alba hath the face in Remembraunce
Of dame Custance and thereon mused he
If that the childes moder were ought she
That is his wif and pⁱrively he Sighed
And sped hym from the table that he myght
Per fay he thought the fantome is in my hede
I ought deme of skilfull Iuggement
That in the Salte see my wif is dede
And afterwarde he made his argument
What wote I if crist hath hir hidder sent
My wif be see as wele as he hir sent
To my contree fro thens she was went
And after noen home with the Senatoure
Gothe alba for to sene this wonder chaıı̄unce
This Senatoure dothe alba grete honoure
And hastely he sente after Custaunce
But trust me wele hir list not to daıı̄unce
When that she wiste wherfore was that sonde
Vnnethe vppon hir fete she myght stonde
Whan Alba Sawe his wyf faire he hir grete
And wept that it was routhe for to se
For at the firste loke that he on hir sette
He knewe wele verrely that it was she
And for Sorowe as dombe stant as a tre
So was hir herte shette in hir distresse
When she remembre his vnkyndnesse ¶
Twys She swouned in his owne Sight
He wept and hym excused pitously
Now god qd he and his hallowes bright
So wissely on my soule as haue mcy
That of youre harme as giltles am I
As is maurice my sone so lyke yoᵘur face
Elles the fende me fecche oute of this place
Longe was the Sobbyng and the bitt̉er/re peyne
Or that hir wofull hertes myght cesse
Grete was the pite for to here hem pleyn
Through which pleyntes bigan her woo encresse
I pray you all my laboure to relesse
I may nought telle her woo till to morowe
I ame so werye forto speke of her sorowe
But fynally when the sothe is wiste
That alba giltles was of hir woo
I trowe an hundred tymes ben they kyste
And such ablisse is be twix hem twoo
That saue the Ioye that lasteth eủer/re moo
There is none like that any creature
Hath sene or shall while the worlde may endure
Tho praide she hir housbonde mekely
In relef of hir longe peynes pyne
That he wolde prey hir Fader specially
That of his maieste he wolde enclyne
To vouche sauf some day with hym to dyne
She preide hym eke he sholde by no way
Vnto hir Fader no worde of hir sey
Some men wolde seyne howe that the childe maurice
Dothe this message vnto this Emꝑper/paroᵘur
But as I gesse alba was nought nyse
To hym that was of so soủer/reeyn honoure
As he that is of all cristen folkes the floure
Sente any childe but it is bette to deme
He wente hym self and so it may wel seme
This Emꝑper/paroᵘur hath graunted gentylly
To come to dyn as he hym besought
And wele rede I he loked bisely
Vppon the childe and on his dought̉er/re thought
Alba goth to his Inne and as hem thought
Arrayeth for the feste in eủer/rey wise
As ferre forthe as connyng may devise
The morowe come and Alba gan hem dresse ¶
And eke his wyff the Emꝑper/paroᵘur forto mete
And forthe they ride in Ioye and in gladnesse
And when she sawe hir Fader in the strete
She light a doun and falleth hym to fete
Fader seide she youre yonge childe Custaıı̄unce
Is nowe full clene oute of yoᵘur remembraıı̄unce
I ame youre doughter Custance qd she
That whylome ye sente into Surree
It am I Fader that in the Salte see
Was put allone and dampned for to deye
Nowe Fader for goddis loue I you crye
Sende me no more into the hethennesse
But thanke my lorde of his kindnesse
Who can the piteous Ioye telle all
Be twix hem thre Syn they ben thus y mette
But of my tale make an ende I shall
The day gothe faste I wil no leng lette
Thes gladde folkes to dyn they hem sette
In Ioye and blisse at mete I lete hem dwelle
A thousande folde more then I can telle
This childe Maurice was Sithen Emꝑper/paroᵘur
Made bi the pope and lyved cristyently
And to cristes chirche he did grete honoure
But I lete all this story passe by
Of Custaıı̄unce is my tale specially
In olde romayns gestes men may fynde
Maurices lif I bere it nought in mynde
This kyng Alba when he his tyme se
With his Custance his holy wyf so white
To Englonde be they come the right way
Where as they lyve in Ioye and Inquiete
But litell while it laste I you hete
Ioye of this worlde longe tyme wil not abide
Fro day to nyght it chaungeth as the tyde
Who lyveth after in swyche delite a day
That ne meveth either conscience
Or Ire or talent or some kyn affray
Envye or pride or passioıı̄un or offence
I ne sey but for this ende thus sentence
That litell while in Ioye or in plesaunce
Last the blisse of alba with Custaıı̄unce
For dethe that taketh of highe and lowe his Rente
When passed was a yere even as I gesse ¶
Oute of this worlde this kyng Alba he hente
For whome Custaıı̄unce hath full grete hevynesse
Nowe lete vs prey god his soule blesse
And dame Custance fynally to seye
Towarde the rome the Cite gothe hir weye
To Rome is come this hoolye Creature
And founde hir Frendes hole and sounde
Nowe is she scaped all hir auenture
And when she hir Fader hath y founde
Doun on hir knees she falleth to grounde
Weping for tendirnesse of herte blythe
She thanked god a hundred thousand sythe
In vertue and hooly almes dede
They lyven all and neủer/re a sondrye wente
Till dethe departe hem this life they lede
And fare nowe well my tale is at an ende
Nowe Ihu Crist that of his myght may sende
Ioy after woo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs all that ben in this place ¶Amen/
¶Incipit prologus Armigeri/
Oure hoste vppon his styrropes stede anoone
And seide good men herkenyth eủer/reychone
This was a thryfty tale for the nones
Sir paresshe preste qd he for goddis bones
Telle vs a tale as was thy forwarde lang ore
I se wele that ye lyrned men in lore
Conne myche good by goddis deynte
The persone hym answerde benedicite
What aylleth the so synfully to swere
Oure hoste answeryd O Iankyn be thy chere
I smelle a lollere in the wynde qd he
Howe good men herkenyth me qd oure hoste
Abide for goddis deigne passioıı̄un
For we shall haue a predicacioıı̄un
This loller wil preche vs some what
Nay be my Fader soule that shall he not
Saide the squier here shall he nought preche
He shall no gospell glose here ne teche
He leueth all in the grete god he
He wolde sowe some defficulte
Or spill Cokhill in oure clene corne
And therfore hoste I warne the be forne
My Ioly body shall a tale telle ¶
And I shall Clynke you so mery a belle
That I shall wake all this company
But it shall nought be of physosophyephylosophyephyslosophye
Be physlyas ne termes queynt of lawe
There is but litell latyn in my mawe

div.l: (base) And certeynly he hath it wel disserued

Here Endeth the Sompnoᵘurs tale and next be
Gynneth the Clerke of Oxinforde
Sir Clerke of Oxinforde oure hoste saide
Ye ride as Coye as ye were a maide
Were newe spoused sittyng at the borde
This day herde I of youre mouthe a worde
I trowe ye studye a boute some Sophyme
But Salamon seith eủer/ree thing hath tyme
For goddis sake as beth of better chere
It is no tyme forto studye here
Telle vs some mery tale by yoᵘur faye
For what man that is entred in aplaye
He nedes moste vnto the playe assente
But preche not as Frerers done in lente
To make vs for oure olde synnes wepe
Nor that thy tale make vs not to slepe
Telle vs som merye thing of aventours
Youre termes youre colours and youre fygours
Kepe hem in store al so be that ye Endite
Highe stile is when that men to kyngs write
Speketh so playne at this tyme we you pray
That we mowe vnderstonde that ye say
This worthy clerke benignely answerde
Hoste qd he I am vnder youre yerde
Ye haue of vs as nowe the goủer/renaıı̄unce
And therfore wil I do you obeyssaıı̄unce
As ferre as resone axeth hardely
I wil you telle a tale which that I ¶
Lyrned at padowe of a worthy clerke
As provyd by his worde and his werke
He is nowe dede and nayled in his cheste
I pray to god yeven his soule good reste
Fraunceys petrak the lawreate poete
Hight this clerke whose rethoryke swete
Enlumyned al ytaylle of poetrie
As lynyan did of philosophie
Or lawe or other arte perticulere
But dethe that wil not suffer vs to dwelle here
But as it were a twynkelyng of an Eye
Hem bothe hath sleyne and al shul we deye
But forthe to towne of this worthy man
That taught me this tale as I be gan
I seye that firste with the sale enditeth
Or he the body of his tale writeth
A ꝑper/parrohem in the which discryueth he
Premonnde and of Saluces the contre
And speketh of appenyn the hilles highe
That bene the boundes of westlumbardye
And of the mounte vesulus in special
Where as the pole oute of the welle smal
Taketh his firste spryngyng and his sours
That Estwarde aye encreseth in his cours
To Emielwarde and forthe vnto venyse
The which a longe thyng were to devise
And truly as to my Iuggement
Me thinketh it a thyng Inpartment
Save that he wil conveyen his matere
But this is his tale which that ye may here
¶ Here Endeth the Clerkes prologe
And here begynneth his Tale
Ther was in the westesyde of ytalye
Doun at the rote of vesulus the colde
A lusty playne habundaıı̄unt in vetayle
Where many a toure and town thou maiste se be holde
That foundyn were in tyme of Faders olde
And many another dilectable sight
And Saluces this noble contre hight
Amarques whilome lorde was of that londe
As were his worthy elders hym be fore
And obeysaunt aye redy to his honde
Were al his lieges bothe lesse and more ¶
Thus in delite he lyved and hath done yore
Be lovyd and drad through favoᵘur of fortoıı̄un
Bothe of his lordes and eke of his comoıı̄un
There with he was to speke of lynage
The gentillest borne of al lumbardye
A fair persone and stronge of age
And ful of honoure and of Curtesye
Discrete Enough his contre forto gye
Saue in some thinges that he was to blame
And Waltere was the yonge lordes name
I blame hym that he consydred nought
In tyme cōmmyng what myght hym be tyde
But on his luste present was al his thought
As forto hawke and hunte on eủer/rey syde
Wele nyghe al other curys lete he slyde
And eke he nolde and that was worste of al
Wedde no wyff for no thyng that myght be falle
Only his peple that poynte bare so sore
That flokmele uppon a day they to hym wente
And oone of hem that wisest was of lore
Or elles that the lorde wolde beste assente
That he shulde telle hym what his peple mente
For wele couthe he shewe suche matere
And he to the marques seide as ye shul here
O noble marques youre humanite
Assureth vs and yeveth vs hardynesse
As ofte tyme is of necessite
That we to you may telle oure hevynesse
When that we fele any diseses or distresse
That we with pitous herte come to compleyn
And lete not youre Eres oure vice disdeyn
Al haue I not done in this matere
More than another hath right in this place
Yete for asmych as ye my lorde so dere
Haue al wey shewed me Favoure and grace
I dar the better axe of you a space
Of audience to shewe oure requeste
And ye my lord to done as ye lyste
For certeis lorde so wele vs liketh you
And al yoᵘur werke and haue done that we
Ne couthe not oure self devisen howe
We myght lyven in felicite
Saue oone thyng if it yoᵘur wil be ¶
To be a wedded man if that ye liste
Then weʳᵉ youre peple in Soủer/reayne hertes reste
Boweth youre hede vnder that blessful yoke
Of soủer/reaynte and not of seruice
Which that men clepe spousayle or wedloke
And thinketh amonge youre wittes wise
Howe that oure dayes passeth in sondry Gyse
For though we ryme wake slepe or ryde
Aye fleeth the tyme it wil no man abide
Though youre grene youthe floureth as yite
In Crepith age as stil as any stone
And dethe manaseth over age and smyte
In eiche estate for there escapeth none
And also certeyn as we knowe eichone
That we shal deye and vncerteyn we al
Ben of that day when dethe wil on vs falle
Accepteth than of vs the true entente
That yite neủer/re refused oure heste
And we wil lorde if ye wil assente
Chese you a wyf in shorte tyme at the leste
Borne of the gentillest and of the meste
Of al the londe so that I oughte seme
Honoure to god and you as we can deme
Delyủer/re vs of al this besy drede
And take a wyffe for highe goddis sake
For if it so be falle as god forbede
That throwe youre dethe youre lyne shulde slake
And that a straunge successoure shulde it take
Youre herytage o woo were vs on lyve
Wherfore we pray you hastely to wyve
Her meke prayer and her mery chere
Made the marques herte to haue pite
Ye wil qd he myn owne peple dere
That I neủer/re thought erste strayne me
I me reIoysed in my liberte
That selde tyme is founde in maryage
There I was fre I moste be in seruage
But neủer/re the lesse I se youre true entente
And truste on youre wit haue done aye
Wherfore of my Fre wil I wil assente
To wedde me as soone as eủer/re I may
But there as ye haue proferde me to day
To chese me a wyff I you relese ¶d
That choyse I pray you of youre ꝓprofre sese
For god it wote that children often bene
Vnlyke her worthy Elders hem be forne
Bounte cometh al of good not of the strene
Of which they be gendred and y borne
I trust in god and eủer/re haue done beforne
My maryage in myn estate and reste
I hym be take ye may do as ye lyste
Lete me aloone in chesyng of my wyff
That charge vppon my bak I wil endure
But you I pray and charge vppon yoᵘur lif
What wyff that I take that ye me ensure
To wyrche whiles youre lif may dure
In worde and werke bothe here and eủer/rey where
As she an Emꝑper/parours doughter were
And firther more this shal ye swere that ye
Ayeinst my choyse shal make no noyse ne stryf
For Sith I shal for go my liberte
There as my herte is sette there wil I wyve
And with hir lede my lust and my lyve
And but ye wil assente in suche manere
I pray you speketh no more of suche matere
With herty wil they sworne and assenten
To al this thyng there saide no wight nay
Besechyng hym of grace er they wenten
That he wolde graunte hem a certeyn day
Of his spowsaile as sone as eủer/re he may
For yite al wey the peple dradde
Leste the marques wolde no wyffe wedde
He graunted hem suche a day as hem luste
In which he wolde be wedded sekyrly
And saide he did al this at her requeste
And they with humble entente buxsomely
Knelynge vppon her knees ful reủer/reently
Hym thankyng al and this they haue an ende
Of her entent and home ayein they wende
And here vppon he toke his officers
And cōmmaundid for the feste to purveys
And to his pdue knyghtes and squiers
Suche charge yove as he luste on hem laye
And they to his cōmmaundmentes obeye
And eiche of hem dothe al his deligence
To done vnto that highe reủer/reence ¶
NOught ferr from that paleys honourable
There as this marques shope his maryage
There stode a thorpe of sight dilectable
In which that pore folke of that village
Hadden her bestes and her herbage
And of her laboure toke her sustenaunce
Aftir that the Erthe yave hem habundaunce
Amonge this pore folke there dwelled a man
Which was y holde poreste of hem al
But highe god some tyme sende can
His grace into an oxe stalle
Ianicola of the thorpe hym calle
A doughter hadde he faire Enough to sight
And Gryssylde this yonge maiden hight
Forto speke of vertuous and honeste beaute
Then was she oone the Faireste vnder sonne
And ful pore Fostred vp was she
No licourus luste was thrugh hir ronne
Wele ofter of the welle then of the wyne tonne
She dranke and for she wolde vertue plese
She knewe wele laboure but none ydel ese
But though this mayden so tender were of age
Yete in the breste of hir virgynite
There was yclosed rype and sadde corage
And in grete reủer/reence and charite
Hir olde pore Fadir Fostred she
A fewe shepe spynnyng on the felde she kepte
She wolde not be ydel til that she slepte
And when she homwarde come she wolde brynge
Wortys or other herbes tymes ofte
The which she brought for hir levyng
And made hir bedde harde and no thyng softe
And she kept hir Fadirs lyfe on lofte
With eủer/rey obeisaunce and deligence
That childe myght do to the Faders reủer/reence
Vppon Gryssilde this pore creature
Ful ofte this marques keste his Eye
As he rode on huntyng parauenture
And when it felle that he myght hir espye
He nought with wantone lokyng of Folye
His Eyen caste on hir but in sadde wyse
¶ Cōmmendyng in his herte hir womanhede ¶
And eke hir vertuous passyng any wight
Of so yonge age as wele in hir chere as in hir dede
For though the peple hadde grete in syght
He consydred in vertue ful right
Hir beaute and disposed that he wolde
Wedde hir oonly if eủer/re he wedde shulde
The day of weddyng came but no wight can
Telle what woman it shulde be
For which mvayle wondred many a man
And saide when they were in pduete
Wil oure lorde lyve yite in vanite
Wil he not wedde alas the while
Why wil he hym self and vs be gile
But neủer/re the lesse this marques hath do make
Of gymes sette in golde and in asure
Broches and rynges for gryssildys sake
And of hir clothyng toke he the mesure
Of a maide like vnto hir stature
And eke of hir other ornementes al
That vnto suche a weddyng shulde fal
The tyme of vndryn on the same day
Approched that the weddyng shulde be
And al the paleys put was in araye
Bothe halle and chambres eiche in his degre
Houses of offices stuffed with grete plente
There maiste thou se of dayntevous vytayle
That may be founden as fer as lasteth Itayle
This royal marques richely arrayed
Lordes and ladies in his companye
The which that to his feste was prayed
And of his retynne the bachelerye
With many a sown of sondrye melodye
Vnto the village of which I tolde
In this araye the right waye they holde
Gryssilde god wote of this was ful Innocente
That for hir shapyn was al this aray
To Fette watere at the welle is she wente
And cometh ageyn as soone as eủer/re she may
For wele she herde sey that Ilke day
That the marques shulde wedde and if that she myght
She wolde feyne haue sene some of that sight
She thought she wolde with other maidens stonde
That be my felawes in oure dorre and se ¶
The marquys and therfore wil I founde
To done at home as soone as it may be
The laboure the which that longeth vnto me
And than I may at leyser hir beholde
If she this way vnto the castel holde
And as she wolde oủer/re the thressholde gone
The marques came and bigan hir forto calle
And she sette doun hir water potte anoone

That whilome were al my hertes reste
That I shal go I wil go when ye liste
But there as ye me ꝓprofre suche dowere
As I first brought it is wele in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thing feire
The which to me nowe were harde to fynde
O good god how gentyl and howe kynde
Ye semed bi youre speche and bi youre vesage
The day that made was oure mariage
But sothe is saide al wey I finde it true
For in effect preued it is on me
Love is not olde as when it is newe
But certeis lorde for none adủer/resite
To deyen in this case it shal not be
That eủer/re in worde or wil I shal repente
That I to you yaf myn herte in hole entente
My lorde ye wote that in my Fadirs place
Ye did me strype oute of my pore wede
And richely ye me clad of youre grace
To you brought I not elles oute of drede
But feith nakidnes / and my maidenhede
And here ayein my clothing I restore
And eke my weddyng ryng for eủer/re more
The remenaıı̄unt of youre Iewels redy they be
Within youre Chambre I dare it saufly seyn
Nakid oute of my Fadirs house qd she
I came and nakid moste I torne ageyn
Al youre plesaunce folowe wolde I feyn
But yite I hope it be not youre entente
That I smokles oute of youre paleys wente
Ye couthe not do so dishonest a thing
To that wombe in which youre children lay
Shulde be forne the peple in my walkyng
Be se al bare wherfore I you pray
Lete me not like a worme go bi the way
Remembre you myn owne lorde so dere
I was youre wyf though I vnworthy were
Wherfore in guerdoıı̄un of my maidenhede ¶d
Which that I brought and not ayein I bere
As vouchesafe yeve me to my mede
But suche a smok as I was wonte to were
That I therwith may wrye the wombe here
That was yoᵘur wyf and here I take my leve
Of you myn owne lorde lest that I you greve
The smok qd he thou haste vppon thy bak
Lete it be stil and bere it forthe wᵗith the
But wele vnnethe that worde he spake
But wente his wey for reuthe and pite
Be forne the folke hir self striped she
And in hir smok with fote and hede al bare
Towardes hir Fadirs house is she fere
The folke hir folowen weping in the weye
And fortune ay they cursen as they gone
But she fro wepyng kept hir Eyen drye
Ne in his tyme worde spake she none
Hir Fadir that this tiding herde anone
Cursed the tyme and the day that nature
Shope hym to be a lyvous creature
For oute of doute this olde pore man
Was eủer/re in suspect of hir mariage
For euer he demed sith that it be gan
When that the lorde hadde fulfilled his corage
He wolde think it were a disperage
For his estate so lowe forto light
And voyden hir as soone as eủer/re he myght
Ayeinste his doughter hastelych goth he
For be noyse of Folke he knewe hir comyng
And wᵗith hir olde cote as it myght be
He coủer/reed hir ful sorowfully wepyng
But on hir body myght he it not bryng
For rude was the clothe and she more of age
Be dayes fele than was hir maryage
Than wᵗith hir Fadir for a certeyn space
Dwelled this floure of wyfly pacience
That neither bi hir worde ne bi hir face
Be forne the folke ne in her absence
Ne shewed she that there was done offence
Ne of hir highe estate no remembraunce
Hadde she as be any man of cōmtenaunce
No wonder was for in hir grete Estate
Hir goste was eủer/re in pleyn humilite ¶d
No tender mouthe no herte delicate
No pompe no semblaunt of royalte
But ful of pacient benignite
Discrete and pridles and aye honoᵘurabil
And ay to hir housbonde meke and Stabil
Men speke of Iobe and moste for his humblenes
As clerkes when hem liste can wele endite
Namely of men but in Sothfastnes
Though clerkes preis women but a lite
There can no man in humblenes hym aquyte
As a woman can ne can be half so true
As women but it be fal of newe
Fro Boleyn the Erle of Pavyk is come
Of which the fame vpsprong bothe more and lesse
And in the peplis Eris al and some
Was tolde that he a newe marqueces
With hym brought suche pompe and riches
That neủer/re was se wᵗith mannes Eye
So royal a Sight in al weste lumbardy
The marquis that shope and knewe al this
Or that this Erle was come sente his message
Of that cely pore creature the marqueces
And she with humble herte and glad vesage
Not with no swellyng thought in hir corage
Can at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reủer/reently and wisely she hym grette
Gresilde qd he my wil is ful entierly
This maiden that shal be wedded vnto me
Resseyued be to morowe as royally
As it is possible in myn house to be
And eke that eủer/rey wight in his degre
Haue his Estate in Sittyng and in Seruice
And hem plesaunce as ye can beste device
I haue no woman sufficiaıı̄unt certeyn
The Chambres forto aray in ordinaıı̄unce
Aftir my lust and therfore wolde I feyne
That thyn were al suche man of goủer/renaıı̄unce
Thou knowest eke of olde al my plesaıı̄unce
Though thyn aray be bad and evil besey
Do thy deuer at the beste wey
Not only lorde that I am glad qd she
To do youre luste but I desyre also
You first to plese and serue in my degre ¶d
With oute faynyng and shal eủer/re mo
Ne for no wele ne for no man wo
Ne shal the goste within my herte stynte
To loue you best wᵗith al my true entente
And with that worde she gan the house to dight
And tablis to sette and beddis forto make
And peyned hir to do al that she myght
Praying the Chambrers for goddis Sake
To hastien hem and faste to swepe and shake
And she the moste seuisable of al
Hath eủer/rey Chambre araied and eke his halle
Aboute the vndren gan this Erle alight
That with hym this noble Children twey
For which the peple ranne to the Sight
Of her aray mightely they were be sey
And than amonge hem al they sey
That Walt̉er/re was no fole though that hym liste
To Chaunge his wyf for it was for the beste
For she is fairere as they demen al
Then is Gresilde and more tendir of age
And fairere fruyte be twene hem shulde falle
And more plesaunce for hir highe lynage
Hir brother eke so feire of visage
That hem to se the peple hath caught plesaunce
Cōmmendyng nowe the marques goủer/renaıı̄unce
O sturdy peple vnsad and eủer/re vntrue
Aye vndiscrete and chaungyng as a van
Aye ful of clappyng dere ynowe a Ian
Youre dome is fals yoᵘur constaıı̄unce Evyl pveth
A ful grete fole is he that on you levyth
Thus seide sad folke in that Cite
When that the peple gadred vp and doun
For they were right glad for the newelte
To haue a newe lady of her town
No more nowe of this I make mencioıı̄un
But to Grysilde ageyn I wil me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir besynesse
Ful besy was Gresilde in eủer/rey thing
That to the feste was partinent
Right nought was she a basshed of hir clothing
Though it were rude and eke somdele to rente
But with glad chere she to the yate wente
With other folke to grete the marqueces ¶d
And after dothe forthe hir besynesse
With wele glad chere the gestes she resceyued
And buxomly eủer/reych in his degre
That no man defaute there perceyued
But eủer/re they wondred what she myght be
That in so pore aray was for to se
And knewe suche honoᵘur and reủer/reence
And worthely thei preis hir prudence
In al this meen while she ne stynte
This maiden and eke hir brothir to comende
With al hir herte and benigne entente
So wele that no man couthe hir preysing amende
But at the laste when thes lordes wende
To Sitten a doun he gan to cal
Gresilde as she was besy in the halle
Gresilde quod he as it were in his play
Howe liketh the my wyf in hir beaute
Right wele my lorde qd she for in good fay
A fairer saugh I neủer/re none then she
I prey to god to yeve you ꝓprosperite
And so hope I that he wil to you sende
Plesaunce Enough vnto youre lives ende
But O thyng I beseche you and warne also
That ye ne prick with no turmentyng
This tendre may as ye haue done moo
For she is fostred in hir norysshyng
Wele tendirly in hir yonge pleying
She coude not adủer/recite endure
As coude a pore fostred creature
And when this walt̉er/re saugh hir pacience
Hir glad chere and no malice at al
And he so ofte hath done hir offence
That she eủer/re constant and Sad as a wal
Conteynyng eủer/re hir Innocence oủer/re al
This Sturdy marques gan his herte redresse
To rewe vppon hir wifely stedfastnesse
This is Enough Gresilde myn owne qd he
Be now no more a gaste and be nowe wele apaide
I haue thy faithe and thy benignite
As wele as eủer/re womans was assayed
In grete estate and porely arayed
Nowe knowe I dere wif thy stedfastnes
And hir in armes toke and gan to kys ¶d
And she for wonder toke here of no kepe
She herd not what thing that he saide
She ferde as she had sterte oute of hir slepe
Til she out of the madnes abraide
Gresilde qd he be god that for vs deied
Thou arte my wyf and none other I haue
Ne neủer/re had as god my soule save
This is thi doughter which thou haste supposed
To bene my wif and none othir feithfully
The tothir shal bene myn heire as I eủer/re disposed
Thou bare hem in thy body truly
At boleyn haue I kept hem sekirly
Take hem ayein for I myght not Sey
That thou haste lorne eny of thy childer twey
And folke that other wise haue saide of me
I warne hem wele that I haue done this dede
For no malice ne for no cruelte
But forto assay thi womanhede
And not for to sle my children god forbede
And forto kepe hem pduely and stil
Til I thi purpose knewe and al thy wil
And when she this herde doun she falleth
For pitouse Ioy and aftir hir swonyng
She bothe hir yonge childer calleth
And in hir armes pitousely wepyng
Enbraced bothe tendirly kissyng
Wele like a modir with hir Salte teres
She bathid bothe hir vesage and hir Eres
O which a pitouse thing it was to se
Hir swonynges and hir pitouse voyce to here
Gramercy my lorde god I thanke and you qd she
That ye haue savid my children dere
Now reke I neủer/re to be dede right here
Syn I stonde in youre love and in yoᵘur grace
No force of dethe ne when my sperites pace
O tender O dere O yonge children myne
Youre woful modir wende stidfastly
That cruel houndes or some vermyne
Had etyn you but god of his mcy
And youre benigne fadir tendirly
Hath done you kept and at that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapped to the grounde
And in hir swone so sadly helde she ¶d
Hir Children twoo when she gan hem brace
That with grete sleight and difficulte
The children from hir armes thei gan to race
O many a tere O many a pitouse face
Doun ran of hem that stode beside
Vnnethe a boute hir myght thei abide
Walt̉er/re hir vp takith and hir Sorwe gladeth
She ariseth vp al a basshid fro hir traunce
And eủer/rey wight hir Ioy and feste maketh
Til she hadde caught ayein hir coıı̄untenaıı̄unce
Walt̉er/re dothe hir so feithful plesaunce
That it was deīmte to se the chere
Be twixt hem twoo nowe they ben met infere
Thes ladies when they her tyme say
Haue taken hir and to Chambre gone
And stripen hir oute of hir rude araye
That in a clothe of golde that bright shone
With a Crown of many a riche stone
Vppon hir hede thei hir into the halle brought
And there she was honoured as she ought
Thus hath this pitouse day a blisful ende
For eủer/rey man and woman dothe his myght
This day in myrthe and revel to dispende
Til on the welkyn shone the sterres bright
For more solempne in eủer/rey mannes Sight
This feste was and gretter of costage
Then was the Revel atte mariage
Wele many a yere in highe ꝓprosperite
Lyven thes twoo in concorde and in reste
And richely his dought̉er/re maried he
Vnto a lordes sone of the worthiest
Of al ytaile and then in pees and reste
His wifes Fadir in his courte he kepeth
Til that his Soule oute of his body crepith
His Sone entrith into his heritage
In reste and pees aftir his Fadirs day
And fortunate eke was he in mariage
Al put he nought his wif in assay
This worlde is not stronge it is no nay
As it hath bene in olde tymes yore
And herkenyth what the auctoᵘur seith therfore
This storye is saide nought that wifes sholde
Folowe Gresilde as in humilite ¶d
For it were inportable though thei wolde
But that eủer/rey wight in his degre
Sholde be constant in adủer/resite
Thi storie with highe stile endite
With pacience Gresilde he quyte
And syn a woman was so pacient
Vnto a mortal man wele we aughte
Receyve al in gre that god vs sente
For grete skilles he previth that he bought
But he tempteth no man that he bought
As seith seynt Iame if ye his pistle rede
He provith folke alday it is no drede
¶ And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourge of adủer/resite
Wele ofte to betyn in sondry wise
Not forto knowen vs for certeis he
Or we were borne knewe al oure freelte
And for oure beste is al oure goủer/renaıı̄unce
Let vs it haue than in vertue sufferaıı̄unce
¶ But oone witt herkenyth lordynges er ye go
It were ful harde nowe a dayes
In al a town fynde Gresildis twoo or thre
For if thei were in soche assaies
The golde of hem hath nowe so harde allaies
With Bras that though it be kinde at the eye
It wil rather breste atwoo than plye

(base) As for to worche eny thing in contrarie /
(base) Vnto his wille certes neuer schal he thriue
(base) Though that he multiplie terme of his lyue
(base) And there a poynt for ended is my tale /
(base) God sende euery trewe man boote of his bale amen
(base) ¶ Heere is ended the Chanoıı̄uns Yemannes tale ~

div.l: And next be gynneth the doctoᵘur of physik ꝓprologe
When this yoman his tale endid had
Of this false chanon which was so bad
Oure hoste gan say truly and certeyn
This preest was begiled sothely to sayne
He wenyng forto be a philosopher
Till that he no golde lefte in his cofer
And sothely this preest had a litle Iape
This Cursed chanon put in his hode an ape
But all this passe I oủer/re as nowe
Sir doctoᵘur of phesyk I pray you
Telle vs a tale of some honeste matere
It shall be done if ye wil it here
Saide this doctoᵘur and his tale be gan a noon
Now good men qd he herkenyth eủer/reychone
(base) ¶ Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
(base) THer was as telleth Titus Liuius
(base) A knyght that called was Virginius
(base) Fulfild of honour and of worthynesse
(base) And strong of freendes and of greet richesse
(base) ¶ This knyght a doghter hadde by his wif
(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
(base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is
(base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
(base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
(base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
(base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
(base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Which afterward may greve þeim sore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
(base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
(base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
(base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede
(base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
(base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
(base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
(base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas
(base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
(base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
(base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale

body.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.

div.l: (base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
