div.l: And here be gynneth the Pardon his ꝓprologe
LOrdynges qd he in chirche when I preche
I payne me to haue an hautyf speche
I ryng it oute as rounde as gothe a belle
For I can all be rote that I telle
My tyme is all wey oone and eủer/re was
Radix omniıı̄un malorum est Cupiditas
First I ꝓpronounce whens that I come
And than my bullys shewe I all and some
Oure liege lordes seale is my patente
Then shewe I firste my warent
That no man be so bolde preest ne clerke
Me to distourbe of cristes holy werke
And after that tell I forthe my tales
Bullys of popis and of cardynallys
Of patryarkes and of bisshops I shewe
And in latyn to speke a wordes fewe
To savoryn with my predicaciou
And forto styrr̉er/re folke to deuociou
Then shewe I forthe my longe Cristall stones
Y crammed full of cloutes and of bones
Relikes they bene as wenyn they eichone
Then haue I in latyn a sholdre bone
Which that was an holy Iewes shepe
Good men say I take of my wordes kepe
If that this bone be wasshe in any welle
If cowe er calf shepe er oxe swell
That any worme hath hurte er stonge
Yeve hym the water and lete hym gange
And yite also firther more
Of pokkys and scabbys and eủer/rey sore
Shall eủer/rey shepe be hole that of this welle
Drynketh a Draught taketh kepe what I you telle
If that the good man that the bestes owe
Wil eủer/rey weke er that the cok crowe
Fastyng drynke of the welle a Draught
As the holy Iewe oure elders taught
His bestes and his store shall multeplye
And sirres also it heleth Ielosy
And thoghe a man be falle in Ielous rage
Lete make with this wat̉er/re his potage
And neủer/re shall he more his wyf mystruste
Though he the sothe a faute by hir wiste ¶ Pardon /
All had she taken prestis tweyn or thre
Here is a metayne eke that ye may se
He that his hande wil put in that metayn
He shall haue multeplying of his grayn
When he hath sowen be it whete or otes
So that ye dele pens or elles grotes
And men and women O thing warne I you
If any wight be in this chirche nowe
That hath done synne orrible that he
Dare not for shame y shreuen be
Or any woman be she yonge or olde
That hath made hir housbonde Cukwolde
Such folke shall haue no power nor grace
To offre to my reliques in this place
And who so findeth hym oute of blame
They wil come vp and offre in goddis name
And I assoyle by the auctorite
Such that by bull was graunted me
Be this garde haue I wonne eủer/rey yere
An hundred marc̉er/re sith I was pardonere
I stonde like a clerke in many a pulpete
And shewe to lewde peple and doun they sitte
I prece so as ye haue herde be fore
And telle an hundred Iapes more
Than payne I me to strecche forthe my neck
And este and weste vpon the peple I bek
As dothe a douve sittyng vpon a berne /
Myn handes and my tonge gothe so yerne
That it is Ioye to se my besynes
Of averise and suche cursednes
To yeve her pens and namely vnto me
For myn entent nys not but forto wynne
And no thing for no correcciou of synne
I rek neủer/re when they bene buryed
Though that her soules gone a blakberyed
For certeis many a predicaciou
Sowneth of Euyll entenciou
Some for plesaunce of folke and for flatery
To bene a vaunsed by ypocrosy
And some for vayne glorie and some for hate
For when I dare not other wise debate
Then wil I stinge hem wᵗith my tonge smerte
In preching so that he shall not asterte ¶/
To bone defamed falsly if that he
Hath trespassed to my brethern er to me
For though I tell not his ꝓpropre name
Men shall wele knowe it is the same
By symonye and by other circıı̄unstaıı̄unce
Thus quite I folke that dothe vs displesaıı̄unce
Thus spitt I oute my venyme vnder hewe
Of holynesse to seme holy and true
But shortly myn entent I wil devise
I preche of no thing but of Couetise
Therfore my teme is yite and eủer/re was
Radix omniıı̄un malorum est cupiditas
Thus can I preche the same wise
To such as ben suande the synne of averice
But though my self be gilte in that synne
Yite cane I make other folke forto wynne
Frome auerice and sore to repente
But that is not my pⁱrincepall entente
I preche no thing but for Couetise
Of this matere it ought Enowe suffice
Then telle I of ensaumples many oone
Of olde stories longe a gone
For lewid peple levyn tales olde
Which they can wele reporte and holde
What trowe ye whiles that I may preche
To wynne golde or silủer/re forto teche
That I wil lyve in poủer/rete wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neủer/re truly
For I wil preche and begge in sondry londes
I wil not do no laboure with my handes
And make baskettes and lyve therby
Be cause I wil not begge ydilly
I wil none of the apostels countirfete
I wil haue money chese or elles whete
All were it yeuen of the porest page
Other of the porest wedowe in a village
All shulde her children sterve for famen
Nay I wil drynke the licoᵘur of the wyne
And haue a Iolye wenche in eủer/rey towne
But herkenyth lordinges in conclusiou
Youre liking is that I shall telle a tale
Nowe haue I dronke a draught of ale
By god I hope I shall tell you a thing ¶/
That shall resone be to youre liking
For though my self be a full vicious man
A morall tale to you tell I can
Which I am wonte with preching forto wynne
Nowe holde yoᵘur pease my tale I wil be gynne

¶ Here endeth the pardoners prologe
¶ And here begynneth his tale
In flaundres some tyme were a company
Of yonge folke that hauntyd folye
As Ryote hasarde stewes and Tavernes
And such other vnworthy games and playes
They daunce and playe at the stewes all night
And etyn also and dronken oủer/re her myght
Throwe which they do the devyll sacrefice
Within the devilles temple in cursed wise
The suꝑper/parfluytes abhomynable
Her othes bene so grete and dampnable
That it is grysly forto here hem swere
Oure blessed lordes body they to tere
Hem thought the Iewes rente hym not Enoıı̄ungh
And ilke of hem at other synnes loughe
And right anoone come Inn tomblesters
Feteyse and small and yonge froycestrys
Syngers with pipers bawdes wafreres
Suche bene the devilles vere officeres
To kindle and blowe the fyre of lecherye
That is annexed vnto glotonye
This holy writ take I to witnesse
That lecherye is in wyne and dronkennesse
Lo howe that dronken hath vnkindly
Lay by his doughters twoo vnwetingly
So dronke he was he nyste what he wrought
And therfore he repente hym ought
Herodes who so wil his storye seche
There may ye sene and by Exaumple teche
When he of wyne was replete at his feste
Right at his owne table yaf his heste
To sle the baptist Iohn full giltles
Senek saithe eke good wordes doutles
He seith he can no difference fynde
Be twix a man that is oute of his mynde
And a man that is dronkelewe
But that wodnesse is falle in a shrewe ¶/
Perseủer/reeth leng then dothe dronkennesse
O glotonye full of Cursednesse
O cause firste of oure confusiou
O originall of oure Dampnaciou
Till crist had bought vs wᵗith his blode ageyn
Lo howe dere and shortly was to seyn
A boute was this cursed velanye
Corrupt was this worlde throwe velanye
Adam oure Fadir and his wife also
From paradise to laboᵘur and to woo
Were dryven oute for that wise it is no drede
For whiles that Adam fasted as I rede
He was in paradise and when that he
Ete of the fruyte defended on the tree
Anoone he was oute caste to woo and pyne
O gloteny on the wele vs ought to playne
O wiste a man how many maledies
Foloweth of excercise and of glotones
He shulde be the more mesurable
Of his dyete sittyng at the table
Alas the shorte throte the tender mouthe
Maketh that Este and weste northe and southe
In Erthe in ayre in watir men do swynke
To gete a glotone mete or drynke
Of this matere O poule wele canste thou . entrete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe to mete
Shall god destroye bothe as poule seyth
Alas so foule a thing it is be my feith
To sey this worde and fowler is the dede
When men so drynketh of the white and Rede
That of his throte he maketh his pⁱriuee
Thrugh that cursed suꝑper/parfluyte
The apostle wepyng seith full pitously
There walken many of which you tolde haue I
I sey it nowe he weping with pitouse voyce
They bene Enemeys of cristes croyse
Of which the ende is dethe the wombe is her god
O wombe O bely O stinking cod
Fullfuled of donge and of corrupciou
At eyther ende of the foule is the sown
Howe grete coste and laboᵘur it is to fynde
Thes cokes howe they stampe streyn and grynde
And turne substaunce into accident ¶/
To fulfill thy licorouse talente
Vpon the harde bones knoken they
The mare for they caste nought a wey
That may through the golete softe and soote
Of spicerye and of the leues the barke and rote
Shall be his sause y made be delite
To maken hym a nother appetite
But certeis he that hunteth such delites
Is dede while he levyth in this vices
A lecherouse thing is wyne and dronkennesse -
It is full of stryving and of Cursednesse
O dronken man disfigured in thy face
Foule is thy brethe foule arte thou to enbrace -
And throwe thy dronkennesse sowneth thy sowne
As though thou saidest aye sampson sampsou
And yite god wote sampsone dranke neủer/re no wyne
Thou farest as it were a sticked swyne
Thy tonge is loste and all thy honeste cure
For dronkennesse is verrey sepulture
Of mannes witte and his discreciou
He can no counseylle kepe it is no drede
Now kepe the frome the white and from the rede
Namely from the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle in fysshe strete er in chepe
This wyne of spayne crepith subtilly
Into other wynes growyng faste by
Of suche riseth suche fumosite
That when a man hath dronke draughtes thre
And weneth that he be in the bulle in chepe
He is in spayne right in the towne of lepe
Not at the Rochell nor at burdeux towne
And then wil they sey sampson sampsou
But herkenyth lordynges oo worde I you pray
That all the soủer/reayne actes dare I say
Of victorious in the olde testamente
That throwe god verrey god that is omipotent
Were done in astynence and in pride
Loketh the bible and there ye may lerne
Loketh Atilla the grete conqueroᵘur
Deied in his slepe with shame and dishonoᵘur
Bleding at his nose in dronkennesse
A Capitayne shulde lyve in sobernesse
And oủer/re all avise you right welle ¶/
What was comaundid to latmuell
Not Samuell but lamuell sey I
Redeth the bible and fynde it expresse
Of wyne yeuyng to hem that hath Iustice
No more of this for it may wele suffise
And nowe that I haue spoken of glotone
Nowe wil I defende you hassardrye
Hassardys veray moder is of lesynges
And of disseite and cursed forswerenes
Blaspheme of cristes manslaught and waste also
Of cataile and of tyme and ferther moo
It is repreve and contrarie to honoure
Forto be holde a comyn hasardoure
And eủer/re the higher that he is of state
The more is y holden desolate
If that a prince vse hasardrye
In all gouủer/reance and all pollesye
He is as be comen apynnyou
I holde in the lasse reputaciōmu
Stilbone that was a wise enbasitoᵘur
Was sent into garneth wᵗith grete honoᵘur
Fro Calidony to make hym allyaıı̄unce
And when he came hym happed this chaıı̄unce
That all the gretteste that were of that londe
Pleying at the hasarde he hem founde
For which as soone as that myght be
He stale hym home into his contree
And saide here I wole not lese myn name
I wil not take on me so grete defame
You forto alye to none hasardoures
Sendeth other wise enbassetoures
For be my trouthe I had leủer/re deye
Then I to you haserdores shulde alye
For ye that ben so glorious in honoure
Shall not alye you with an hasedoure /
As be my wil ne as be my trete
This wise philosopher as this saide he
Loke howe eke the king Damatrius
The king of percys as the boke seith vs
Sente hym a payre of dise of golde in scorne
For he had vsed hasardey there be forne
For which he loste his glorie and renoun
And was y holde at no reputaciōmu ¶/
Lordinges myght fynde other man of play
Honeste Enough to dryve the day a way
Nowe wole I speke of othis fals and grete
A worde or twoo as other bokes entrete
Grete sweryng is a thing abhomynable
And false sweryng is more reprouable -
The highe god for bade sweryng at all
Witnesse of mathewe but in speciall -
Of sweryng seith holy Ieremye
Thou shalte swere sothe and not lye
And swere in dome and in rightwisenesse
But ydle sweryng is a cursednesse -
Be holde and se in the first table
Of high goddis hestis honorable
How that the seconde heste of hym is this
Take not my name in ydelnes amys
Lo redeth here forbedeth he such sweryng
Than homyside or any other cursed thing
I say as by other thus it stondeth
Howe that the seconde heste of god is that
And firther more I wil telle the all plat
That vengeaıı̄unce shall not parte from his house
That is of his othis so outetrageously
Eye bi goddis pcious herte and his naylys
And be his blode that is in hayles
Sevyn is my chaunce and thyn is v. and iij.
Eye goddis armes if thou fals playes wᵗith me
This dagger shall throwe thyn herte go
This fruyte cometh of the bechyd bones twoo
For sweryng the falsnesse A my side
Nowe for the loue of crist that for vs deyed
Levyth yoᵘur othes bothe grete and smale
For cristes sake and herkenyth to my tale
Thes Ryotōmures thre of which I telle
Longe or pryme ronge anny belle
Were sette hem in a tauerne to drynke
And as they sate they herde a belle clynke
Be fore a corps that was caryed to his grave
That on hem gan calle to his knave
Go bett qd he and axe redely
What corps it is that passeth forth by
And loke that thou reporte his name welle
Sir qd this boy it nedeth neủer/re a dele ¶/
It was me tolde or ye come here ij . owres
It was parde an olde felawe of youres
All sodenly was slayne to night
For dronke as he sate on his benche all night
There come a pⁱriue thefe men clepen dethe
That in this contre all this peple sleeth
And wᵗith his spere he smote his herte in twoo
And wente his way wᵗith oute wordes moo
And maister er ye come in his psence
He hathe slayne a thousand this pestilence -
Me thinketh it were necessarie
Bethe redy forto mete hym eủer/re more
This taught me my dame I sey no more
O seynt Marie saide thus Tauernere
The childe seith sothe for he hath slayne ij . here
Hens oủer/re a myle within a grete village
Bothe man and woman childe and page
I trowe that his habitaciou be right there
To bene avised grete wisdome it were
Or that he did a man such dishonoᵘur
Ye goddis armes saide this Ryatoᵘur
Is it suche perell with hym forto mete
I shall hym seke by goddis dyne bones
Lete eiche of vs be comen othere brother
And eich of vs holde vp his hande to othir
And we wil sle this fals traytoᵘurs dethe
He shall be dede so many men sleeth
By goddis dignite or that it be night
To geder haue thes thre her hertꝭes plight
To lyve and deye eich of hem wᵗith other
Though that he were his owne dere brother
And vp they sterte all dronke in this Rage
And forthe they gone towarde the village
Of which the taủer/renere hathe spoke by forne
And many a grysly othe haue they sworne
And cristes blessed body they to Rente
Dethe shall be dede if we may hym hente
When they haue gone not fully A myle
Right as they wolden haue trodyn oủer/re a stele
An olde pore man wᵗith hem he mete
This olde man full mekely hem grete
And seide thus lordinges god you se
The proudest of thes Ryotoures thre ¶/
Answerd what carle with an harde grace
Why arte thou all for wryed save thy face
Why levyst thou so longe in grete age
This olde man gan loke in her vesage
And saide thus for I can not fynde
A man though I walke into ynde
Nouther in Cite nor in village
That wil chaunge his youthe for myn age
And therfore moste I haue myn age stille
As longe tyme as it is goddis wil
Nor dethe alas wil not haue my lif
This walke I like a recheles Caytif
Vpon the grounde which is my moders gate
I knocke with my staff Erely and late
And sey leve moder lete me Inn
Lo howe I vanysshe flesshe blode and skynne
Alas when shall my bones be at reste
Modir with you wolde I chaunge my cheste
That in my Chambre longe tyme hath be
Yee for an Ere cloute to wrap in me
But yite to me she wil not do that grace
For which full pale and wreched is my face
But sirs to you it is no curtesye
To speke to an olde man anny villonye
But I trespassed other in worde or in dede
Ye may youre self in holy writ rede
Ne do to none olde no harme nowe
In age if ye shall longe a bide
And god be with you whether ye go or ryde
I moste go thidder there as I haue to done
Nay olde cherle be god thou shalte not se
Saide this other asardoure anone
Thou partist not so lightely be seynt Iohn
Thou spake right nowe of that traytoᵘurs dethe
That in this contre all oure frendes sleeth
Haue here my trouthe thou arte his aspie
Telle where he is or thou shalte a bye
By god and be the holy sacrement
Thou arte oone of his assente
To sle vs yonge folke thou false thefe
Nowe sirs if that it be to you lefe
To fynde dethe turne vp this croked way
For in that I lefte hym be my fey ¶
Vnder a tree and there he wil a bide
For youre boste he wil hym no thing hide
Se ye that oke right there ye shall hym fynde
God saue you that bought all mankynde
And you amende thus saide that olde man
And eủer/rey of this Ryotoures tho they ran
Till they come to the tree and there they founde
Of florence fyne golde y coigned rounde
Wele nyghe a vij busshels as hem thought
No lenger after dethe then they sought
But eiche of hem was so glad of that sight
For that the florence so faire ben and bright
That doun they sette hem by this pssious horde
The werste of hem spake the firste worde
Bretherne qd he take kepe what I saye
My witte is grete though I bourde and playe
This tresoᵘur hath fortune vnto vs yeve
In myrthe and Iolite oure life forto lyve
And lightly as it cometh so wole we spende
Eye goddis pcious dignite who wende
To day that we shulde haue so faire a grace
But myght this golde be caried from this place
Home to my house or elles to youres
Then myght we say it were all oures
Then were we in highe felicite
But truly be day it may not be
Men wil sey that we were thevys stronge
And for oure owne tresoᵘur done vs honge
This tresoᵘur moste be caryed by night
As wisely and as slely as it myght
Wherfore I rede to loke amonge vs all
Drawe Cutte lete se where that it wil befalle
He that hath the Cutte with herte blithe
Shall renne to the towne and that full swythe
To bryng vs brede and wyne full pⁱriuely
And twoo of vs shall kepe full subtilly
This tresoᵘur wil and if ye wil not taryen
When it is night we wil this tresoᵘur carien
Be oone assente where as vs beste luste
That oone of hem brought in his fyste
And bade hem drawe and loke on whome it wolde falle
And it felle on the yongest of hem all
And towarde the towne he wente anoone ¶/
And also soone as he was gone
The tone spake vnto the tother
Thou wottest right welle thou arte my sworne brother
Thy ꝓprofete wil I telle the right anoone
Thou wotteste wele that oure felawe is gone
And here is golde and that full grete plente
That shall departed amonge vs thre
But neủer/re the les if I can shape it so
That it departed were amonge vs twoo
Had I not done a frendes torne to the
The tother answeryd I not howe it myght be
I wote wele the golde is oures twoo
What shulde we say what shulde we do
Shall it be counceylle saide the firste shrewe
And I shall telle it in wordes fewe
What we shall do and bryng it wele a boute
I graunte qd the other with outen doute
That be my trouthe I wil not the be wrye
Nowe qd he thou wottest wele we ben tweye
And tweyn of vs shall streng be than oone
Loke when he is sett and that anoone
Arise as though thou woldest wᵗith hym playe
And I shall ryve hym thrugh the sides tweye
Whiles thou strogelyste wᵗith hym in game
And with thy dagere loke thou do the same
And than shall all this golde departed be
My dere frende be twix the and me
Then may we bothe oure bostes fulfill
And pley at the dise at oure owne will
And this acorded be this shrewes twey
To sle the thrid as ye haue herde me sey
The yongest which that wente to the towne
Full ofte in herte he rolled vp and doun
The beaute of this florence newe and bright
O lorde qd he if so were that I myght
All this tresoᵘur wynne to my self aloone
There is no man that leveth vnder trone
Of good shulde lyve so merye as I
And at the laste the fende oure Enemye
Put in his herte that he shuld poysone bye
With which he myght sle his felawes tweye
For why the fende founde hym in suche levyng
That he had leve hym to sorowe brynge ¶
For this was vtterly his entente
To sle hem bothe and neủer/re to repente
And forthe he gothe no leng wolde he tarye
Into the towne vnto a potecarie
And praide hym that he wolde hym selle
Some poysone that he myght his rattes quelle
And eke there was a polcat in his hawe
That as he saide his capons y slawe
And saide he wolde avenge hym if he myght
The potecarie answerid thou shalte haue
A thinge that so god my soule saue
In all this worlde there is no creature
That etyn or drynken of this confectoure
Not but the mountenaıı̄unce of a corne of whete
That he ne shall anoone his life forlete
And sterve he shall and that in lasse while
Then thou woldest passe but a myle
This poysone so stronge is and so violent
This cursed man hath in his hande it hente
This poysone toke he of this man
He put it in a boxe and sithen he ranne
And borowed hym large botelles thre
To his felawes ayein repayreth he
And in the tweyn the poysone poured he
The thrid he kept clene for his drynke
For all night he shope hym forto swynke
In carying of that golde oute of that place
And when this Ryotoᵘur wᵗith sorye grace
Had filled hym his grete botelles thre
To his felawes ayein repaireth he
What nedeth it to ʆser/sirmone therof more
For right as they had caste his dethe be fore
Right so they haue hym slayne right anoone
And that this was done than spake that oone
Nowe lete vs sitte and drynke and make vs merye
And aftirwarde it happed hem ꝑper/par caas
To take the botell there the poysone was
And dranke and yave his felawe drynke also
For which anoone they steruen bothe twoo
But certeis I suppose that Avycene
Wrote neủer/re nor caton ne Galien
Mo wonder sorowynges of enpoysennyng
Then had thes wrecches at her endyng ¶/
Thus endid be this homysides twoo
And eke the fals enpoyson also
O cursyd synne full of Cursidnes
O traytours homysides O wikkednes
O glotony O luxury O hasardry
Thou blasflem of Crist wᵗith veleny
And othis grete of vsage and pride
Alas mankinde howe may it be tide
That to thy creature which that he is rought
And with his precious blode also the bought
Thou arte so fals and so vnkinde alas
Nowe good men for reve you yoᵘur trespas
And ware you of the synne of auerice
My holy pardone may you warysshe
So that ye offre nobles or sterlinges
Or elles silủer/re sponys broches and rynges
Boweth yoᵘur hede vnder this holy bulles
Come vp and offre of yoᵘur wolles
Howe many names here I enter in my Rolle anoone
Into the blisse of heuyn shull ye gone
I you assoyle be my highe power
Ye that wil offre as clene and as clere
As ye werne borne lo sirres howe I preche
And Ihu Crist that is oure soules leche
So graunte you this pardone to resseyve
For that is loste I wil not assoyle
But sirres O worde forgate I in my tale
I haue reliques and pardone in my male
As faire as any man in Englonde
Which were me yeve by the popis honde
If any of you wil of devociou
Offeryn and haue myn absoluciou
Cometh forthe anoone and knele here a doun
And mekely resseyve my pardou
Or elles take pardou as that ye wende
All newe and fresshe at eủer/rey townes ende
So that ye offre alwey newe and newe
Nobles or pens which that ben good and true
It is an honoᵘur to eủer/reyche that is here
That ye may haue a sufficiant pardon
To assoyle you in contre as ye ride
For Auentours which that may be tide
For parauentoᵘur man falle or twoo ¶
Doun of his horse and breke his nek a twoo
Loke which it is to you all
That I am in yoᵘur felawship y falle
That man assoyle you both more and lasse
When that the soule shall frōm the body passe
I rede that oure hoste shall be gynne
For he is moste envolupid in synne
Cometh forthe sir hoste and offerith right anoone
And thou shalte kis the reliques eủer/reychone
Yee for a grote vnbokle anone this purs
Nay qd he than haue I cristes curs
Lete be qd he it shall not be so theche
Thou woldest make me kys thyn olde breche
And swere it were a Relequyk of a seynte
Though it were with thy foundment depaynte
And by that crosse the which seynt Elyn founde
In stede of reliques other of seyntwarye
Lete Cutte hem of and I wil the helpe hem to carye
They shull be shryned in an hogges torde
This pardon answerd not oone worde
So wrothe he was he wolde no worde say
Nowe qd oure hoste I wil no leng play
But right anoone this worthy knyght be gan
Wᵗith the no wight none othir angry man
When that he saıı̄ungh that all the peple loughe
No more of this for it is right Enoıı̄ungh
Sir Pardon be merye and glad of chere -
And ye sir hoste that be so leve and dere
I pray you that ye kys this pardon
And Pardon I pray the drawe the nere
And as we ryde lete vs laughe and play
Anoone they kissed and riden forth her way

¶ Here Endeth the pardon his tale And here begynneth
oure hostys wordes and the shipmans tale

div.l: (base) It shalbe done by god and by seint Iohn
(base) Seid the Maryner as wel as eủer/re I . can
(base) And right anone his tale he beganne
Here bigynneth the Shipmannes tale
A Marchant whilom dwelled at Seint Denys
That riche was for which men helde hym wys
A wyf he hadde of excellent beautee
And compaignable and reuelous was she
Which is a thyng that causeth moore dispence
Than worth is al the cheere and reuerence
That men hem doon at festes and at daunces
Swiche salutacions and contenances
Passen as dooth a shadwe vpon the wal
But wo is hym that payen moot for al
The sely housbonde algate he moot paye
He moot vs clothe and he moot vs arraye
Al for his owene worship richely
In which array we dauncen iolily
And if that he noght may parauenture
Or ellis list no swich dispense endure
But thynketh it is wasted and ylost
Thanne moot another payen for oure cost
Or lene vs gold and that is perilous
This noble Marchant heeld a worthy hous
For which he hadde alday so greet repair
For his largesse and for his wyf was fair
That wonder is but herkneth to my tale
Amonges alle hise gestes grete and smale
Ther was a Monk a fair man and a bold
I trowe a thritty wynter he was old
That euere in oon was drawyng to that place
This yonge Monk that was so fair of face
Aqueynted was so with the goode man
Sith that hir firste knewliche bigan
That in his hous as famulier was he
As it is possible any freend to be
And for as muchel as this goode man

and they that bene wrothe wote not
wele that they done nor what they sayen

therfore the
ꝓprophete saith troubled een hath no clere sight ~ ~

Then saide dame prudence I make no semblaunte
of wrath nor of angre but for youre ꝓprofete

for Sa-
lamon saith he is more wrothe that chideth or reproveth a
fole for his folye shewyng hym semblaunt of wrath

then
he that supporteth hym and preiseth hym in his mysdoyng
and laughyng at his folye

and this same Salamon saith
that by the sorowfull countynaıı̄unce of a man

the fole certeis
teche hym self and amendeth ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

Then saide Mellebe I shall not can answere to so
many resons as ye putten to me and shewen

and saith shortly yoᵘur will and youre councelle and I am redy
to ꝑper/parfourme and fullfill it ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

Then dame prudence discoủer/reed all hir wil vnto hym
and saide

I concelle you a bove all thinges that
ye make pees betwene god and you

and reconsiled vnto hym
and to his grace

for as I haue saide you be fore god hath
suffred you to haue this tribulacioıı̄un for youre synnes

and if
ye do as I say you god wil sende youre adủer/resaries vnto
you

and make hem all redy to youre fete to do youre will
and youre cōmmaundment

for Salamon saith for when the con-
ducioıı̄un of a man is plesaunte and liking vnto god

he chaıı̄un-
geth the hertes of the mannes adủer/resaries and constrayneth hem
to besechyn hem of pees and of grace

I pray you lete me speke wᵗith
youre adủer/resaries in pⁱriue place

for they shull not knowe that
it be of youre wil of yoᵘur assent

and then when I knowe her will
and her assent then may I councelle you the more savourly

dame
qd Mellebe dothe yoᵘur will and yoᵘur liking

for I put me holye in
youre disposiciou and ordynaunce ~ ~ ~ ~

Thenne dame prudence when she sawe the good will of
hir housbonde she delyủer/reed and toke a vice in hir self

thinking howe she myght bryng this nede to a good conclusiou
and to a good ende

and when she sawe her tyme she sente for
thes adủer/resaries to come to hir into a pⁱriue place

and saide vnto
hem in this wise howe that they ought to haue grete repen-
taunce

of the Iniure that they hadden to Mellebe hir lorde done
and to hir and to her doughter ~ ~ ~ ~

And when they had herde the goodly wordes of dame
prudence

they were so supplisshed and Ravisshed and
had so grete Ioye of hir that wonder was to telle

A lady quod
they ye haue shewed vnto vs the blessyng of swetnesse

certeis
qd they we put oure dede and oure matere and oure cause all only
in yoᵘur good will

and be redy to obey the cōmmaundement of oure
lorde Mellebe
oute of mesure

that we be not a power to make hym
amendes

and therfore we oblige vs and oure frendes to do his cōm-
maundement

but ꝑper/parauentoᵘur he hath suche heuynesse and suche
wrathe vnto vs warde for cause of oure offence

that he will
Ennoyen vs in suche man payne that we may not bere it

and
therfore lady we beseche youre womanly pite

to take suche avise-
ment that we nor oure frendes be not destroyed with folye ~
CErteis qd dame prudence it is a grete folye

a man
to put hym in arbitracioıı̄un and power of his Enemye
for Salamon saithe

to thy wyfe to thy Frende ne to thy bro-
ther

ne yeve thou myght ne maistry of thy body whiles thou
liste

nowe seth that he defendeth that he shall not yeve the
myght of his body

be stronge resone he defendeth a man to
yeve hym self to his Enemye

and neủer/re the lees I councell you
that ye mystrust not my lorde

for I knowe wele that he is
meke and large

and no thing desyrous ne couetous of good
ne Riches

for there is no thing that he desireth save worship
and honoᵘur

firther more I knowe that he shall no thing do in
this nede with oute my councelle

and I shall so worche in this
case that by the grace of god ye shall be reconsiled vnto vs

Then saide they all with oone voyse worshipfull lady
we put vs and oure goodes and oure will fully in
youre disposisciou

and be redy forto come what day that ye
lik
of youre noblenesse to calle vs and to bynde vs

as stronge as it
liketh you of youre goodnesse
and the wil of oure lorde Mellebe

When dame prudence had herde the answere of thes men
she bade hem gone ageyn pⁱriuely

and she retoᵘurned ageyn
vnto hir lorde Mellebe and tolde hym howe she founde his adủer/resarijs
full repentaunt

knowlechyng her synnes and trespace and how
they were redy to stonde
to his mercy and pite ~ ~ ~

Then saide Mellebe he is worthy to haue pardone and
foryevnesse of his synne that excuseth hym not of his
Synne
but repenteth hym and axeth Indulgence

and I conferme
wele to haue pees

but it is good that we do not with oute the
assent of oure Frendes

¶ Than was prudence Right glad and
Ioyfull and saide

certeis sir qd she ye haue goodly and wele
answerde

for Right as by councell assente and helpyng of yoᵘur
frendes ye haue be styrred to venge you and make werr

right
so wᵗith outen her councell shull ye nought acorde you to haue
pees with youre adủer/resaries

for the lawe saithe there is no
thing so good be way of kinde as a thing to be bounden to
hym that was y bounde

and then dame prudence wᵗith outen de-
lay or tarying sent anoone Messyngers for her kynne and for
her olde frendes which that were true and wise

and tolde by
ordre in presence of Mellebe all the matere as it is a boven ex-
pressed and declared

and praide hem to yevyn hir a wise coun-
celle what beste was to done in this matere

And when Melle-
beus councelle hath taken her avice and good deliberaciou of the
forseide matere

and had examyned and by right grete besynesse
and grete deligence

they yeuen full councell forto haue for
to haue pees and reste

and that Mellebe shulde resseyue it
with good herte of his adủer/resarijs to foryevnesse and mcy

and
when dame prudence had herde the assent of hir lorde Mellebe
and the councell of her frendes

acordid with hir wil and
entencioıı̄un
she was wonder glad in hir hert and saide

there
is an olde prouerbe qd she saith the goodnesse that thou
maiste do this day do it

and a bide no delay not till to mo-
rowe

and therfore I councell you that ye sende youre messangs
which that bene discrete and wise

vnto yoᵘur adủer/resarijs telling
hem in yoᵘur be half
if they wil trete of pees and of acorde

that
they shapen hem with outen delay or thing to come to vs
which thing parfourmed was dede

and when thes tres-
passoures and repentyng folke of her folye that is to say
the adủer/resarijs of mellebe

had herde what thes messangers
of mellebe saide vnto hem

they were full glad and Ioyfull
and answerde full mekely and benignely

yeldyng graces and
thankes to her lorde Mellebe and to all his company

And sho-
pyn hem with oute delaye to go with the messyngers and to
obey the cōmmaundment of her lorde Mellebe

and right anoone
they toke her way to Mellebe

and toke the some of her true
wordes and of her frendes to maken faith for hem and for to
bene her borowes

and when they come to the psence of Mellebe
he saide hem thes wordes

¶ It stondeth thus qd Mellebe and
sothe it is that ye
causeles and with outen skyll and resone

haue done grete Iniurijs and wronges to me and to my
wiffe dame prudence and to my dought̉er/re also

for ye haue
Entred into my house with violence

and haue done suche
outrage that all men knowen wele that ye haue disserued
dethe
and therfore wil I knowen and wetyn of you

whedyr
ye wil putten the punysement and chastysing and the
vengeaıı̄unce of this outrage in the wil of me and of my wif
dame prudence or ye wil not ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

Then the wisest of hem thre answerd for hem all
and saide

sir we knowe welle that we be vnworthy
to come to courte of so grete a lorde as ye bene

for we
haue offended and gilted youre highe lordship

that truly we
haue deserued the dethe

and yite for the grete bonarte and
goodnesse that all the worlde witnesseth of yoᵘur persone

we
submytte vs to youre gracious lordship

and be redy to obey all
youre will and cōmmaundmentes

beseching you to considre our
grete repentaıı̄unce and lowe submissiou

and graunte vs foryev-
nesse of outrageouse trespasse ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

Than Mellebe toke hem vp from the grounde full be-
nignely

and resseyued her obligacions and her boun-
dys and here othys vppon her pleggys

and assigned hem a cer-
teyn day to retourne to his courte
to resseyue her Iugement
with thinges ordeyned eủer/rey man retourned to his owne house

And when dame prudence sawe her tyme she axed
hir lorde Mellebe

what vengeaıı̄unce he thought to
take on his adủer/resarijs ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
O which Mellebe answerde and certeis qd he I thinke

to disheried hem of all that eủer/re they haue and to
exile hem for eủer/re more ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

CErteis qd dame prudence this were a cruell sen-
tence and myche ayeinste resone

for ye haue richesse
Enoughe

and ye myght lightly in this matere gete you a
couetouse name

for the appostle saith that Couetise is rote of
all harmes

for bett̉er/re it is to lese good with worship then to
wynne good with velanye

and as touchyng that ye say
that ye wil exile youre adủer/resaries

that thinketh me mych ayenst
resone and oute of resone

consideryng the power that they haue
yeve vppon hem

and it is writen that he is worthy to lese his
preuelage that mysvseth the myght and the power that is yeve
hym

and I sette in case that ye myght ennioyne hem that payn
by lawe
which I trowe ye may not
put vnto execusiou ꝑper/parauentur
then were it likely to torne to asmych werr as shulde be fore

and
therfore if ye wil that men shulde do you Obeisaunce ye moste
do the more curtesye

and this I pray you in this necessite that
ye haste you to oủer/recome yoᵘur herte

for Senek saith he that oủer/re-
cometh his herte oủer/recometh twys

and Tulliu9 saithe that the
mysse no tokennyng nor thing more comendable in a grete lorde
as when he is bonaire and meke

and I pray you that ye wil
forbere nowe to do vengeance

in suche manere that youre good
name may be kept and conserued

and that men haue cause
and matere to preise you of pite and of mcy

and that ye haue
no cause to repente you of thing that ye haue done before

for Senek saith he oủer/recometh in Evyll man that repenteth
hym of his victorye

Wherfore I pray you lete mcy be in youre
herte

to that entente that god almyghty haue mcy on you in
his laste Iugement

with oute mcy shall be done to hym that
hathe no mcy on a nother wight ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~

Whenne Mellebe had herde the grete skilles and resoıı̄uns
of dame prudence his wiffe and hir wise enforma-
cioıı̄uns

his herte gane enclyne to the wil of his wiff
consideryng hir true Entente

confermed hym anoone and assen-
ted hym to werke aftir hir councell

and thanked god of whome
ꝓprocedeth all vertue and all goodnesse that hym sent a wiffe
of so grete discrecioıı̄un

and when the day come his adủer/resaries
shulde apere in his psence

he spake to hem full goodly and
saide in this wise

all be it so that of youre pride and highe
psumpciou and folye and of yoᵘur necligence and vnconnyng
ye haue mysborne you and and trespassed ageynes me

yite for as
myche as I se youre grete humilite

that ye be so sorye and
repentaunte of youre giltes
it constreyneth me to do you gᵃce

and foryeve you all the offence wronges and Iniuries that
ye haue done ayeinst me
god of his endles mcy

wil at tyme
of my deying foryeve me my giltes the which that I haue
trespassed to hym in this wrecched worlde

for douteles if
that we be sorye and repentaunt for oure synnes and giltꝭes
the which we haue trespassed in the sight of oure lorde god
he is so fre and so mciable
that he wil foryeve vs

and bryng
vs to the blisse that neủer/re shall haue ende amen ~ ~ ~ ~
¶ Here endith Chawcers tale of Mellebe
and prudence and sophia his dought̉er/re /

div.l: Here next foloweth the monkes tale /
Whanne ended was the tale of Mellebe
And of prudence and hir benignite
Oure hoste saide as I am faithfull man
And bi the corpus precious Adryan
I had leủer/re then a barell of ale
That good lefe my wiffe had herde this tale
For she is no thing of suche pacience
As was Mellebes wiffe dame prudence
Be cockys bones when I bete my wiffe
Then amonges vs falleth grete stryffe
And when I bete my knaves
She bryngeth to me the grete clubbed staves
And crieth sleeth the dogges eủer/reychone
And breke bothe bak syde and bone
But there be any neghborowe of myn
Wolde not in chirche to my wife enclyne
Or be so hardy hir to trespace
When she cometh home she raumpeth in my face
And crieth fals wreke thy wiffe
Be corpus dıı̄uns I wil haue thy knyff
And thou shalte haue my distaf and go spynne
From day till nyght right thus she wil begynn
Alas she saide that eủer/re I was shape
To wedde a mylke sope or a cowarde ape
That wilbe oủer/relad of eủer/rey wight
Thou dare not stonde be thy wyfes Right
This is my life but if I wolde fight
At oute at the dorre I mote me dight
Or elles I am loste but that I .
Be like a wilde lyoıı̄un fole hardy
I wote wele she wil do me sle some day
Some neghburgh and then go my way
For I am perilous with knyff in honde
All be it I dare hir not withstonde
For she is bigge in armes be my faithe
That shall he fynde that hir mysdothe or saithe
But lete passe a way fro this matere
My lorde sir monke qd he be mery of chere
For ye shall tell a tale truly
Loo Rochesetre standeth here faste by
Ride forthe my lorde breke not oure game
But be my trouthe I knowe not youre name
Whedir I shall calle you my lorde daun Iohn
Or dame Thomas or Dame albone
Or what house be ye be oure Fadir kynne
Evoute to god thou hast a full faire skynne
It is a gentyll pastore there thou goste
Vppon my feith thou arte some officere
Some worthy sexteyn or some sellerere
For be Faders soule as to my dome
Thou arte a maister when thou arte at home
No pore cloystrere nor no pore novise
But a goủer/renoure discrete and wise
And therwith all of brawne and bonys
A wele faire persone for the nones
I pray to god gyve hym good confusiou
That firste the brought to relegiou
Thou woldest be a tredefoule a right
Haddest thou as grete leve as thou haste myght
To parfourme all thy luste in engendoure
Thou haddest be goten many a creatoure
Alas why werest thou so grete a cope
God gyve me sorowe and I were pope
Nought only thou but eủer/rey myghti man
Though he were shore highe vpon his pan
Shulde haue a wiffe for all this worlde is lorne
Relegiou hath take vp the corne
Of tredyng and we borell men is shrympes
Of feble trees there cometh wrecched ympes
This maketh oure heyres to be so sklender
And feble that they may not wele engender
This maketh oure wyves wil assay
Relegyous folke for they may better pay
Of venus paymentes then mowe we
God wote no lushebours pay ye
But be ye not wrothe though I playe
Full ofte in game a sothe I haue herde saye
This worthy monke toke all in pacience
And saide I wil do all my deligence
As ferr as sowneth to honeste
To tell you a tale or twoo or thre
And if that ye liste to herken hidderwarde
I wil you sayne the life of seynt Edwarde
Or elles tragedise I wil you telle
Of which I haue an hundred in my selle
Tregedye is forto telle a certeyn storye
As olde bokis maken memorye
Of hem that stode in grete ꝓprosperite
And bene fallen oute of highe degre
Into miserie and ended wrecchedly
And they ben verified comenly
Of six fete which men clepen examytron
In prose eke bene endited many oon
And eke in myter in many a sondry wise
Lo this declaryng ought Enough suffise
Nowe herkenyth if thou liste to here
But firste I beseche in this matere
Though I be ordre telle not this thinges
Be it of popes Empoᵘurs or kinges
And aftir her agis as men writen fynde
But telle hem some be fore and some be hynde
As it nowe cometh to my Remembraunce
Haue me excused of my Ignoraunce
¶ Here endeth the ꝓprologe of the monke
And next begynneth his tale
De casibz virosum illustrum ~ ~
I wil be waile in man of tragedie
The harme of hem that stonden in highe degr
And fellen so that there nas no remedie
To bringe hem oute of her adủer/resite
For certeyn when that fortune liste to fle
There may no man of hir the course wᵗithholde
Lete no man triste to blynde ꝓprosperite
Bethe warr of thes ensaumples yonge and olde
Lucifere though he an aungille were
Or as a man at hym wil I begynne
For though fortune may not aungille dere
From highe degre yite fell he for his synne
Doun into helle where he is yite Inn
O lucifere brightest of aungels all
Now arte thou Sathanas thou maiste not twyn
Oute of miserie in which thou arte falle
Lo Adam in the felde of damascene
Which of goddis owne fyng wrought was he
And nought be goten on mannes strene vnclene
And had all paradise saue oone tree
Had neủer/re man so highe degre
As Adam till his mysgoủer/renaunce
Was dryven oute of highe ꝓprosperite
To laboure and to helle and to mysschaunce
Lo Sampsone which was anunciate
By the aungille longe or his natiuite
And was to all myghti god consecrate
And stode in noblenesse while he myght se
Was neủer/re such a nother as was he
To speke of strengthe and therto hardynesse
Vnto his wyffe tolde he his secre
Through that he slough hym self for wrechidnesse
Sampsou this noble myghti champiou
With outen wepyn save his handes tweyn
He sloughe and all to Rente the lyou
Towarde his wedding walkyng by the way
His fals wyff couthe hym plese and pray
Till she his councelle and she vntrue
Vnto his foes his councell gan be wrey
And hym forsoke and toke a nother newe
An hundred foxes toke sampsone for Ire
And all her tayles he to geder bounde
And sette the foxes tailes all on fyre
For he in eủer/rey taile hath put a bronde
And they brente all the cornys in that londe
And eke her olyves and her vynes eke
A thousand men eke he sloughe wᵗith his honde
And had no wepen but an asse cheke
When they were slayne so thrusted hym that he
Was wele nye lorne for which he gan to pray
That god wolde on his payne haue some pite
And sende hym drynke or elles moste he dey
An of an assys cheke that was so drye
Oute of a vangetothe sprange anoone a welle
Of which he dronke shortely to say
Thus halpe hym god as Iudicu gan telle
By verey force at gason on a nyght
Magre of phelistience of that cite
The gates of the towne he vpplight
And on his bak caried hem hath he
Highe vpon an hill as men myght se
O noble and myghti sampsou leve and dere
That stronge and noble hath be in my
In all this worlde ne hath bene thy pere
This sampsou nother dranke syder ne wyne
Ne in his hede come there nother rasoᵘur ne shere
By pcep of the messyng devyne
For all his strength was in his heere
And fully xxᵗⁱ yere by yere
Of Isarell he had the goủer/renaunce
But aftir soone wept he many a tere
For a woman brought hym to mysschaıı̄unce
Vnto his leman dalida he tolde
That in his heeris all his strength lay
And falsely to his foes hym solde
And slepyng vpon hir arme vpon a day
She made to clyppe or shere his heeres a way
And made his fomen all his crafte aspien
For when they hym founde in suche aray
They bounde hym faste and put oute his Eyen
But er his heere was clipped or shave
There was no bounde that myght hym bynde
But nowe is he put in prisou and cave
Where as they made hym at the quern grynde
O noble sampson strengest of mankynde
O whilome Iuge in glorie and in Richesse
Nowe maiste thou wepe with thyn Eyen blynde
Seth thou arte from welthe falle into wrechidnesse
The ende of this Caitif was I shall say
As his fomen maden feste vpon a day
They maden hym there be forne hem play
And this was in a temple of grete array
But at the laste he made a foule fray
For he twoo postes shoke and made hem falle
And doun felle the temple and all there it lay
And slough hym self and eke his fomen all
This is to say the princes eủer/reychone
And eke a thousand bodies were there slayne
With fallyng of the grete temple of stone
Of sampsoıı̄un wil I no more sayne
Be ware be this Ensaumple olde and playne
That no man tell her councelle to her wyves
Of suche thinge as thou wolde haue secre fayne
If that it touche her lymes or her lyves
Of herculus the soủer/reeyn conqueroure
Syngyn his wordes lowde and highe renoun
For in his tyme of strength he bare the floure
He sloughe and rafte the skynn of the lyou
And of Centarus the best a doun
He appies sloughe the cruel bryddes felle
He goldyn appils rafte of the dragou
He drewe oute Cerberus the hounde of helle
He slough the cruell tyraıı̄unt vusurus
And made his horse to frete hym flesshe and bone
He sloughe the verey sarpent veynymous
Of achilles twoo hornes brake he oon
And he slough kakus in a cave of stone
He sloughe the gyaunt antheus the stronge
He sloughe the grysly bore and that anoon
He bare his hede vpon his swerde longe
Was neủer/re wight sith the worlde be gan
That slough so many monstors as did he
Thrugh the wyde worlde his name Ranne
That for his strength and his bounte
And eủer/rey reaume wente he for to se
He was so stronge that no man myght hym lette
In bothe the worldes endes saith the storye
In stide of boundes he of brasse a piller sette
A leman had this noble champiou
That hight dyamere as fresshe as may
And as clerkys maken menciou
She hath hym sente a sherte fresshe and gay
Alas this sherte and weleaway
Envenemyd was subtilly wᵗith all
That or he had wered it half a day
It made his flesshe from his bones falle
But neủer/re the lees some clerkes hir excusen
By oone that heght nesus that it maked
Be as be may I wil not hir excusen
But on his body the sherte he wered all naked
Till the flesshe was from the venyme y slaked
And he sawe none other remedye
In hote coles he hath hym self raked
For with no venyme he wolde not dey
Thus starve this worthy herculus
Lo who may trust on fortune any throwe
For hym that foloweth all this worlde of prees
Or he be ware is ofte leide full lowe
Full wise is he that hym self can knowe
Be ware for when fortune liste to glose
Then waiteth she hir man to doun throwe
By suche a way as he wolde beste suppose
The myghti trone the pcious tresoure
The gloriouse septre and the Royall mageste
That had the king of nabagodonosore
With tonge vnneth may discryved be
He twys wan Irlm that Cite
The vessell of the temple he wᵗith hym lad
At babeloyne was his soủer/reeyn see
In which is glorie and his delite he had
The fairest children of the blode Royall
Of Ierusalem he did do gilde anoone

For which I say if that thou liste to here
Moralite and vertuouse matere
And that wil I if ye will yeve me audience
I wolde full fayne at Cristes Reủer/reence
Do all the besynesse that eủer/re I can
To telle some morall thung to plese god and man
Therfore if ye luste I wil not glose
I wil you telle a mery tale in prose
And Ihu for his grace with me sende
To knytte vp all this feste and to make an ende
To shewe you the way in this vyage
Of that ilke parfite pilgremage
That hight Ierusalem Celestiall
And if ye vouche sauf anoone I shall
Begynne vppon my tale for which I pray
Tell youre avise I can no better say
But neủer/re theles this meditaciou
I put aye vnder correcciou
Of clerkes for I ame not texuell
I take but the sentence trusteth welle
Therfore I make a protestaciou
That I will stonde to correcciou
Vppon this worde we haue assented soone
For as it semed it was forto done
To endyn In some vertuouse sentence And forto¶ꝐPer/Par
And forto yeve hym space and audience
And bade to oure hoste that he shulde to him sey
That all we to telle his tale we pray
Oure hoste had the wordes for vs all
Sir preest qd he nowe faire mote the be falle
Saithe what ye liste and we shall gladly here
And with that worde he said in this manere
Telleth qd he youre meditaciou
And hasteth you that soone ye wil haue done
Bethe fructuouse and that in litle space
And forto do wele god sende vs grace
